Not for Redistribution MAURITIUS (Position on December 31, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Mauritius is the Mauritian Rupee, the external value of which is determined on the basis of its relationship to a weighted basket of currencies of Mau- ritius' major trading partners. Buying and selling rates for foreign currencies are quoted by the Bank of Mauritius (central bank) with asymmetrical margins, amounting to 0.125 percent (buying) and 0.25 percent (selling) in respect of exchange transactions in pounds sterling and U.S. dollars, and 0.1875 percent (buying) and 0.25 percent (selling) in respect of exchange transactions in French francs, using rates obtained on the basis of the fixed peg to the basket of currencies. On December 31, 1987 the buying and selling rates of the Bank of Mauritius were Mau Rs 22.5751 and Mau Rs 22.6599, respectively, per £ stg. 1; Mau Rs 12.1600 and Mau Rs 12.2057, respectively, per US$1; and Mau Rs 2.2454 and Mau Rs 2.2553, respectively, per F 1. Commercial banks are authorized to deal in the French franc, pound sterling, and the U.S. dollar at rates based on the rates quoted by the Bank of Mauritius for these currencies. Spreads allowed between buying and selling rates of the commercial banks for transactions by tele- graphic transfers are up to 1 percent for transactions in the pound sterling, 1.25 percent for the U.S. dollar, 1.6 percent for the French franc, 2.25 percent for the Japanese yen and the Swiss franc, and 2.375 percent for the deutsche mark. Commercial banks' buy ing and selling rates for other foreign currencies1 are determined on the basis of appropriate cross rates in the London market and the cost of forward cover in appropriate cases. Forward exchange facilities in pounds sterling, French francs, and U.S. dollars are made available by the Bank of Mauritius for industries operating in the Export Pro- cessing Zone and for banks engaged in foreign borrowing for on-lending to the sugar sector. The max imum period for forward cover is six mon ths; the forward rates are based on a un iform margin of 3 percent per annum. In addition, companies operating in the export processing zone, and other Mauritian exporters and traders dealing in priority imports are authorized to engage in forward cover transactions in foreign exchange markets abroad through their bankers in Mauritius. Companies operating in the export processing zone and the service zone and certain other companies are authorized to maintain w i th local commercial banks accounts denominated in foreign currencies. They may retain the foreign currency proceeds from exports in foreign currency accounts for a reasonable period of time to meet paymen ts for their imports. A stamp du ty of 45 percent is applied to authorized outward transfers of capital (other than banking funds and repa- 1 The exchange control regulations of Mau r i t ius define foreign currencies as all currencies other than the Mau r i t ian rupee. 336 triation of approved foreign investments) and purchases of gold coin and gold bullion. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Mauritius under powers delegated to it by the Financial Secretary. Commercial banks, as agents of the Bank of Mauritius, are authorized to approve and effect payments for current transactions up to prescribed limits. Trans- actions in excess of authorized limits must be referred to the Bank of Mauritius for prior approval. The Ministry of Trade and Shipping is responsible for the issuance of import and export permits, where required. Prescription of Currency Beginning in 1985, Mauritius no longer makes a dis- tinction between sterling and nonsterling areas for pre- scription of currency purposes. Payments to nonresidents may be made in Mauritian rupees from a nonresident account or in any convertible foreign currency. Similarly, payments from nonresidents may be received in Mauritian rupees from a nonresident account or in any convertible foreign currency. A bilateral payments agreement is maintained with Madagascar. Nonresident Accounts External accounts may be opened by residents and firms of other countries and may be credited with (1) authorized paymen ts by residents of Mauritius, (2) any transfers from other external accounts, and (3) the pro- ceeds of sales to an authorized dealer of any convertible foreign currency by nonresidents. These accounts may be debited with (1) any payment to residents of Mauritius, (2) any transfers to other external accounts, and (3) the cost of purchase of any convertible foreign currency or gold. The ''Non-Resident (External Account) Scheme," reintroduced on September 25, 1985, is intended to provide Mauritians abroad with incentives to transfer their savings to Mauritius and to open accounts with commercial banks in Mauritius in rupees in the form of savings or fixed deposit accounts and in designated foreign currencies in the form of term deposits with a minimum period of one year. Interest on such deposits is exempted from income tax. As long as they are abroad, holders of such accounts are free to transfer at any time balances held therein, together with interest. Any related exchange risk involved in maintaining accounts in designated foreign currencies is borne by the Bank of Mauritius. In addition to the above, there are also Blocked Ac- counts to which are credited funds owned by persons and firms resident outside Mauritius and realized from in- vestments made by them prior to April 5, 1966, as well as funds representing emigrants' assets in excess of Mau Rs 100,000. Such accounts may be credited with payments by residents of Mauritius that have been spe- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution cifically authorized for credit to a Blocked Account and may be debited for certain specified transactions. Funds from Blocked Accounts may, with approval, be invested in Mauritius. Upon the realization of such investments, the proceeds are directed once more to a Blocked Account. Imports and Import Payments Importers must be licensed under the Licenses Ordi- nance. Under the Supplies (Control of Imports) Regula- tions of 1982, all imports other than goods exempted or prohibited, as specified in the third and fourth schedules, respectively, require import permits from the Ministry of Trade and Shipping; the permits are essentially for sta- tistical and tax purposes. Commercial banks are autho- rized to approve and transfer funds for import payments up to an amount not exceeding Mau Rs 200,000 without prior approval from the Central Bank. Certain imports are subject to customs surcharges; a stamp duty of 17 percent based on the c.i.f. value is levied on most imports. Local commercial banks are discouraged from extending credit for imports of goods of lower priority. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles related to imports exceeding Mau Rs 200,000 per transaction require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. Foreign exchange for other purposes, such as foreign travel and gifts, may be provided up to specified limits by the commercial banks without prior reference to the exchange control authori- ties. The basic personal travel allowance is the equivalent of £ stg. 1,200 a person for every two calendar years for travel to any country. A 10 percent tax, together with a surcharge of 10 percent thereon, is levied on all air tickets purchased by Mauritian residents for international travel. The allowance for business travel is the equivalent of £ stg. 100 a day plus £ stg. 20 a day for entertainment expenses. There are established limits for payments and transfers in respect of family support, salary remittances by non-Mauritian nationals, gifts, trade commissions, subscriptions to clubs and societies, publishing rights, advertising outside Mauritius, royalties, professional and technical services, education, and leave salaries. Appli- cations for amounts exceeding the standard allocations may be submitted to the exchange control authorities. Resident and nonresident travelers may take out Mau Rs 350 in domestic currency. Resident travelers may take out foreign currency notes up to the amount of their travel allowance. Nonresident travelers may take out any foreign currency declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of (1) articles made wholly or partially of gold, platinum, or silver; (2) diamonds, precious and semipre- cious stones, pearls, and articles mounted with these; and (3) works of art are prohibited, unless permission is obtained from the Financial Secretary. All exports valued at more than Mau Rs 1,000 and all exports of food products valued at over Mau Rs 50 require an export permit from the Ministry of Trade and Shipping. Exports MAURITIUS of certain foodstuffs, including fruits, are controlled. The Mauritius Sugar Syndicate is the sole exporter of sugar. A graduated tax is levied on sugar exports at the rate of 15.75 percent of f.o.b. value for export volume within the range of 1,001-3,000 tons, and 23.625 percent for exports exceeding 3,000 tons. All export proceeds in any currency other than Mauritian rupees must be repatriated within six months after shipments and offered for sale to an authorized dealer. However, permission may be given to large export-import companies to retain export pro- ceeds for a reasonable period of time to meet payments for imports. Exports of knit shirts and sweaters of cotton, wool, and man-made fibers to Canada and the United States are effected under bilateral export restraint agreements. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any currency other than Mauritian rupees must be offered for sale to an authorized dealer. There is no limitation on the amount of foreign currency notes and coin that may be imported, but not more than Mau Rs 700 in domestic currency notes and coin may be imported by travelers. Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted. Outward transfers of capital are subject to certain restrictions. Nonbank residents of Mauritius may, subject to permis- sion, transfer a reasonable amount of capital to any country on payment of a 45 percent stamp du ty. Nonres- idents also require permission to transfer capital to any country; such transfers are subject to a 35 percent stamp duty. Foreign-owned companies may freely transfer abroad dividends, profits, and interest on capital. Permission for repatriation of capital is not granted for capital brought in before April 5, 1966, irrespective of the country of origin. Proceeds from the sale, liquidation, etc. of foreign capital that may not be repatriated must be credited to Blocked Accounts. However, permission for repatriation of capital is normally given for capital brought in on or after April 5, 1966. Repatriation of capital by foreign investors is tax-free up to the amount of original invest- ment. Any capital gains are blocked. The blocked funds may, however, be released either for transfer abroad against payment of the 35 percent stamp du ty, or for investment in Mauritius without payment of stamp duty. Emigrants may take out, at the official rate of exchange and free of stamp duty, the equivalent of Mau Rs 100,000 from their Mauritian assets when emigrating to any country; this facility is available upon redesignation as a nonresident, which occurs upon departure. The balance of an emigrant's funds must be credited to a Blocked Account; any releases that may be approved for transfer abroad are subject to payment of the 45 percent stamp du ty. Persons emigrating from Mauritius are not entitled to draw their personal travel allowance in addition to the emigration facilities. 337 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MAURITIUS Gold Residents other than the monetary authorities are permitted to hold gold for numismatic purposes (including commemorative gold coins of Mau Rs 200 and Mau Rs 1,000) or as personal jewelry and ornaments. The import and export of monetary gold are prohibited, except when made by the monetary authorities. Imports of gold for industrial purposes are subject to a specific import permit. Exports of articles made wholly or partially of gold, other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler, are prohibited. Payments in respect of private imports of gold coin and gold bullion are subject to the 45 percent stamp duty. Imports of certain jewelry are subject to temporary customs surcharges. Changes During 1987 Imports and Import Payments May 2. The tariff regime was reformed, and the max- imum tariff rate was reduced to 127 percent inclusive of stamp duties. 338 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MEXICO (Position on December 37, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Mexico is the Mexican Peso. There are two exchange markets: the controlled market and the free market. The exchange rate in the controlled market is adjusted daily on the basis, inter alia, of the following factors: (1) the demand and supply of foreign exchange in the controlled market; (2) the objective regarding an adequate level of international reserves; (3) the movement of domestic and foreign prices; and (4) movements in other exchange rate relationships. Transactions at the controlled market rate include: (1) merchandise export receipts (with some exceptions); (2) payments by in-bond industries for wages, salaries, leasings or rents, and the purchase of Mexican goods and services, other than fixed assets; (3) royalties for the use of foreign technologies and patents; (4) payments of principal, interest, and related expenses resulting from financial and suppliers' credits by the public and private sector; (5) payments for imports with some exceptions; (6) expenses in relation to the Mexican foreign service and contributions regarding Mexico's membership in international organizations; and (7) other transactions specifically authorized by the Sec- retariat of Finance and Public Credit (SHCP). Eligible participants in the controlled market may choose to complete the transaction at a retail rate, agreed between participants and the banks, or at the "equilibrium exchange rate," which is determined for the controlled market each day at a fixing session (in the Bank of Mexico), in which representatives of the major banks exchange bids for purchases and sales of foreign exchange; the Bank of Mexico also may submit bids in these sessions. For amounts exceeding US$50,000, transactors may make completion of the deal contingent on the equilibrium exchange rate achieving a particular minimum or maxi- mum value. On December 31, 1987 the "equilibrium exchange rate" in the controlled market for the U.S. dollar was Mex$2,209.70 per US$1, and the buying and selling rates in the same market were Mex$2,193.00 and Mex$2,204.00 per US$1, respectively. Within the free market, no limitations apply to the access to, ownership, or transfer of foreign exchange. On December 31, 1987 the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in the free market were Mex$2,230.00 and Mex$2,260.00 per US$1, respectively. The Bank of Mexico provides, through the Trust Fund for the Coverage of Foreign Exchange Risk (FICORCA), an instrument for forward cover of foreign exchange for the repayment of certain foreign debt obligations in respect of debt contracted or rescheduled on a long-term basis with foreign financial entities and suppliers. On January 1, 1987 the Bank of Mexico began to operate a short-term foreign exchange risk coverage market through which commercial and financial operations are covered against exchange rate fluctuations. The scheme applies only to the U.S. dollar, and the coverage is based on the "equi- librium exchange rate" prevailing on the date of contract. All Mexican credit institutions are authorized to operate in the free market through exchange houses. Mexican banks are prohibited from receiving domestic currency deposits from foreign financial institutions abroad or from non-Mexican exchange houses, except when such funds represent the counterpart of foreign currency sold to a Mexican bank for the purpose of a borrowing operation, or when authorized on a case-by-case basis by the Directorate of International Operations in the Bank of Mexico. Financial institutions located in the areas bor- dering the United States are permitted to open checking accounts denominated in U.S. dollars for Mexican residents. On November 12, 1946 Mexico notified the Fund that it was prepared formally to accept the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Foreign exchange policies are established by SHCP and the Bank of Mexico. The exchange control system is administered by the Bank of Mexico through Mexican credit institutions, which carry out most of the transac- tions in the controlled market. Prescription of Currency Apart from the exceptions described below, there are no obligations prescribing the method or currency for payments to nonresidents, neither in the free nor in the controlled market, but obligations deriving from the selling of foreign exchange in the controlled market must be made in the currencies approved by the Bank of Mexico. In accordance with the payments agreements with Ar- gentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Paraguay, Peru, Uruguay, and Ven- ezuela, controlled market payments to these countries must be made through accounts maintained with each other by the Bank of Mexico and the central bank of the country concerned, within the framework of the multi- lateral clearing system of the Latin American Integration Association (LAIA). Similar arrangements exist with Costa Rica, Cuba, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, and Yugoslavia. Imports and Import Payments In line with the program to replace import licenses and permits with tariffs, import licenses from the Secretariat of Commerce and Industrial Promotion are required for only 329 of the 8,459 items in Mexico's general import tariff, with the exception of temporary imports of raw materials and intermediate goods for export production. For the items subject to licensing, applications for import licenses may cover the applicant's import needs for six months. Import needs are estimated at 20 percent above 339 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MEXICO previous actual imports but may be increased when justified. New licenses are issued only if the applicant can demonstrate that at least 70 percent of earlier licenses have been effectively used. For some commodities "open- end" import licenses may be granted, allowing imports to be effected during a period of six months to one year, subject to an overall limit. Depending on the importer's performance, the license may be renewed repeatedly. Some imports are subject to the payment of a fee of 5 percent of the value of the import transaction; part of the proceeds are allocated to a fund handled by the National Bank for Foreign Trade (BANCOMEXT) and the remainder to the municipalities where in-bond facilities are located. All imports must be accompanied by an exporter's declaration of shipment. Imports by public entities and governmental agencies are subject to prior approval by the Secretariat of Commerce and Industrial Promotion (SECOFI). Beginning December 15, 1987, a new import tariff structure is applied, grouping merchandise into five ad valorem rates, ranging from zero to 20 percent. Imports from member states of the LAIA and other Latin Amer- ican countries are subject to preferential tariffs. A free zone regime is granted for certain regions until June 30, 1991; this regime allows imports to these zones without duties, as long as the goods are not similar to those produced domestically in the same regions. Importers may acquire foreign exchange for the fu ll value of merchandise already imported and for which payment has not yet been made. Importers must register a commitment of use (or devolution) of foreign exchange (CUDD) to obtain foreign currency for advance payments; they have a period of 180 days to show evidence of use of the foreign exchange for payment of imports and associated expenses or to return the foreign exchange if no adequate substantiation of its use is provided. Full advance payment for all imports is allowed if the value of goods does not exceed US$10,000, or if payment is made through letters of credit; in the latter case, there is a 60-day period in which to show evidence of use of foreign exchange. For an import value exceeding US$10,000, only 50 percent advance payment is permit- ted. Advance payment for associated expenses is per- mitted up to maximum authorized percentages (6 percent f.o.b. value for North American imports, and 8 percent f.o.b. value for other regions). Confirmation by suppliers is required for individual transactions exceeding US$10,000. Exporters are allowed to retain foreign exchange proceeds up to 100 percent of their requirements for advance payments of imported inputs. These facilities are also extended to the imported inputs of their domestic suppliers. Payments for Invisibles Except for the items specified below, payments for invisibles are made through the free exchange market. The payments made through the controlled exchange market consist of: (1) principal and interest payments on public and private sector debt with foreign financial 340 entities, foreign suppliers, and Mexican banks; (2) fees related to credits from foreign financial entities, up to 3/4 of 1 percent of the total amount of each credit; (3) expenses of the Mexican foreign service, contributions, and allotments for Mexico's membership in international organizations; (4) expenses related to foreign trade; (5) royalties and obligations deriving from juridical acts in force as of June 1, 1984 and recorded with the National Registry of Technological Transfer, with payments to be made through authorized Mexican banks; and (6) expenses on account of scholarships granted by the National Council of Science and Technology (CONACYT) and those approved by CONACYT or the Bank of Mexico for studies in foreign countries. The contracting of insurance for persons in Mexico, or on property of Mexican ownership, or where the risks are on the account of persons in Mexico, or may occur in Mexico, is permitted only with Mexican companies, except when Mexican firms deem it convenient not to execute such transactions, in which case the prior au- thorization of SHCP is required. The provisions are not applicable to reinsurance. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports do not require licenses. Exportation of a few specified items is prohibited. All merchandise export receipts in excess of US$1,000 a week are subject to surrender requirements in the controlled market, within a standard period of 90 days. Handicraft exports of up to US$8,000 per operation are exempt from the surrender requirement. Special procedures apply for the surrender of export proceeds beyond the standard limit of 90 days. Beginning September 5, 1986, if a sale of foreign exchange occurs beyond the required period without authorization, the applicable exchange rate is only a certain percentage of the rate of the selling day, which varies according to the delay in surrendering the foreign exchange. Exporters of jewelry and precious metals must surrender their proceeds through specifically authorized credit institutions. Exporting enterprises are authorized to open in Mexican banks special accounts in foreign currency; but only proceeds from exports can be deposited in such accounts. Interest payable on these deposits is equivalent to the rate of depreciation of the controlled exchange rate against the U.S. dollar, plus the corresponding Eurodollar deposit rates. Mexican banks are also authorized to accept de- posits in U.S. dollars by Mexican firms and grant loans in foreign currency for the production, shipment, storage, and long-term financing of exports. Such deposits can only be constituted in U.S. dollars and do not earn an interest rate higher than LIBOR plus 1 percent. Individual deposit accounts under this scheme must be for a minimum of US$5,000, with the exception of deposits made by enterprises in the free trade zones and border areas. Payments are made abroad in foreign currency. Under the Program for Integral Promotion of Exports (PROFIEX), a drawback system of import duty payments by exporters and their domestic suppliers is in operation. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution With effect from June 6, 1985, the Federal Government provides a facility called "Certificates of the Right to Import Merchandise for Export" (DIMEX), through which exporters with at least 30 percent value added may import, without permit or license requirement, up to 30 percent of the value of their exports; excluded from the scheme are 297 items of the general import tariff, representing 3.5 percent of total import items. Exporters are also eligible to purchase imported inputs at the controlled market rate, as are importers. In addition, they may use their export proceeds to pay for imports, associated expenses, and recorded financial and suppliers' debt. Under a three-year understanding on export subsidies and countervailing duties concluded between Mexico and the United States on April 23, 1985, Mexico has been granted the benefit of the injury test in countervailing duty investigations, in return for which it has undertaken to phase out export subsidies. Proceeds from Invisibles In-bond industries are required to sell foreign exchange through the controlled market for the equivalent in Mex- ican pesos of the payment they make for items specified in the Exchange Control Decree, including payment of wages, salaries, leasings or rents, the purchase of Mexican goods and services other than fixed assets, local and federal taxes, insurance premiums, interest and other accessory payments pertaining to financing payable in Mexican pesos, as well as any other operational expend- iture within Mexico. This regime does not apply to foreign exchange earmarked for payment of credits granted to third parties by foreign financial institutions for the construction of buildings, or industrial parks whose use or enjoyment has been granted to such in-bond industries, provided it has been agreed that the amount of the benefits from such use or possession be applied to liquidating the aforementioned credits. In-bond industries must sell their foreign exchange no later than the last business day of the month in which such expenditures are made. In addition, they must present to the Bureau of Customs at the SHCP and the Bank of Mexico, within the first 15 business days of each month, information as to the dates and amounts of foreign exchange sold to the country's credit institutions during the month immediately preceding, as well as the amounts of Mexican pesos they disbursed to pay each of the specified items. In-bond industries must effect these foreign exchange transactions through Mexican credit institutions. Capital Foreign investment, including the transfer of funds relating to increment of capital stock as well as payment of dividends, is excluded from the coverage of the controlled foreign exchange market. Accordingly, such activities are effected through the free market and not subject to any restrictions, having only to conform to the MEXICO norms contained in the applicable laws and regulations. Loan proceeds repayable abroad in foreign currency and obtained from foreign financial institutions or Mexican credit institutions are channeled through the controlled exchange market, except when said proceeds are used for the servicing of specified long-term external debt or for import payments. The Federal Government has own- ership and control over certain strategic areas, such as petroleum, basic petrochemical production, radioactive minerals, electrical and nuclear energy, specified mining activities, railroads, mail and banking services, and other activities so stated by Mexican law. In addition, foreign investment is forbidden in the following activities: insur- ance and surety bond companies, investment iunds, stockbroker firms, money exchange establishments, radio and television, the public transportation system, and forestry, as well as any other areas specified as such by the Federal Government. New direct foreign investment must have a majority participation of Mexican capital, except those cases approved by the National Foreign Investment Commis- sion (CNIE). Direct foreign investments in Mexico must be recorded with the National Foreign Investment Regis- try. Applications by foreign individuals or enterprises to acquire more than 25 percent of the capital of a Mexican company require the prior authorization of the CNIE. Under resolutions issued by the CNIE in December 1985 to facilitate inflow of foreign investment, no prior CNIE authorization is required for 100 percent foreign ownership of investment in in-bond industry stocks for stock acqui- sition by foreign investors, if as a minimum, 51 percent of such stocks were foreign-owned prior to such investment. Gold Goldsmiths or manufacturers may acquire nonmonetary gold through authorized Mexican credit institutions at the controlled exchange rate for the elaboration of products earmarked for export. There is a value added tax of 15 percent on sales of nonmonetary gold. Purchases and sales of monetary gold by Mexican credit institutions are exempt from the tax. Monetary gold exports are exempted from foreign exchange surrender requirements, up to a maximum of 200 grams. Gold may be freely bought or sold in Mexico at the free-market exchange rate. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO (Position on December 31, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Morocco is the Moroccan Dirham. The Bank Al-Maghrib fixes buy ing and selling rates for the French franc daily on the basis of variations in the value of the currencies of Morocco's principal trading partners, weighted in accordance with the geographic distribution of Morocco's foreign trade and the pattern of currencies of settlement. Buying and selling rates for most other currencies quoted in Morocco1 are established on the basis of the daily dirham-French franc rate and the cross rates for those currencies in relation to the French franc in the Paris exchange market. On Decem- ber 31, 1987 the exchange rate for the French franc was DH 1.45242 buying and DH 1.45678 selling, per F 1. On the same date, the exchange rate for the U.S. dollar was DH 7.7784 buying and DH 7.8222 selling, per US$1. All sales and purchases of foreign currency are cen- tralized in the Bank Al-Maghrib, but the authorized banks are permitted to offset purchases and sales on behalf of private customers in each currency separately. Each day, authorized banks must purchase from or sell to the Bank Al-Maghrib the balances of their purchases and sales in each currency; transactions are effected at rates fixed by the Bank Al-Maghrib. Compensation between banks is not permitted, so that no foreign exchange market exists in Morocco. The Bank Al-Maghrib also establishes buying and selling rates for transactions with travelers in bank notes, traveler's checks, and letters of credit denominated in "convertible currencies" (the currencies listed in footnote 1, including the French franc but excluding the Tunisian dinar) and specified other currencies;2 the au- thorized banks sell to the Bank Al-Maghrib their excess holdings of bank notes and replenish them at the Bank when necessary. A forward foreign exchange cover facility was estab- lished by the authorities effective June 1, 1979; the facility is available for exports as well as imports of items benefiting from special customs arrangements. Forward contracts for the purchase or sale of foreign exchange that have been concluded between banks and their cus- tomers result in reverse contracts between the banks and the Bank Al-Maghrib. They may be concluded in any foreign currency quoted by the Bank Al-Maghrib for maturity periods ranging from a minimum of 1 month to a maximum of 12 mon ths; the guaranteed exchange rate corresponds to the spot exchange rate, against the pay- ment of a commission of 2 percent a year, of which a share amounting to 0.25 percent is retained by the au- thorized banks; provisions are made for extending con- 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, Finnish markkaa, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Kuwaiti dinars, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Saudi Arabian riyals, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, Tunisian dinars, U .A .E. dirhams, and U.S. dollars. 2 CFA francs and Gibraltar pounds. tract terms, revising contracts in part, or cancelling them in whole or in part. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Exchange Office, an agency under the Ministry of Finance. This Office has delegated the execution of certain exchange control measures to authorized banks. Import certificates and export licenses are issued by the Ministry of Com- merce and must be countersigned by the Exchange Office. Import commitments for liberalized goods are signed by the importer himself; they do not require the visa of the Exchange Office unless the country of origin of the goods is not the country of shipment, or the goods are bought on a c.i.f. basis. A part of the Port of Tangier is designated as a free trade zone and is exempt from taxation and from trade, customs, and exchange controls. Arrears are maintained with respect to external payments. Prescription of Currency For prescription of currency purposes, countries are classified as follows: (1) the payments agreement group, comprising countries with which Morocco maintains bi- lateral payments agreements;3 and (2) all other countries— the "area of convertibility." Certain noncommercial settlements with Algeria are made in dirhams or Algerian dinars through special accounts at the two central banks;4 all settlements with Tunisia are made through accounts denominated in con- vertible dirhams or Tunisian convertible dinars. Imports originating in countries in the area of convertibility may be paid for only in "convertible currencies" negotiated by the Bank Al-Maghrib. Other settlements with countries in the area of convertibility may be made only in con- vertible currencies negotiated by the Bank Al-Maghrib or through Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams. Nonresident Accounts The various types of nonresident accounts are as follows. 1. Foreign Currency Accounts are held by physical or juridical foreign nationals, either resident or nonresident. These may be freely credited with book transfers from abroad, with checks, traveler's checks, or any other means of payment denominated in foreign currency, except foreign bank notes,5 and with foreign currency drawn from the Bank Al-Maghrib following general or special authorization by the Exchange Office. They may be freely debited for book transfers abroad to the account holder or to a third party foreign national, for the surrender 3 Guinea and Mali; however, these agreements are inoperative. 4 This arrangement has been inoperative for some time. 5 With effect from March 21, 1988, crediting with proceeds from the repatriation of foreign bank notes has been permitted. 343 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO of foreign currency to the Bank Al-Maghrib, or for the payment of checks denominated in foreign currency. 2. Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams are re- served for physical or juridical persons of foreign nation- ality, who may be resident or nonresident. These accounts may be credited freely with authorized payments due to residents of countries in the area of convertibility and with dirhams obtained from the sale to the Bank Al- Maghrib of convertible currencies, including bank notes.6 They may be debited freely for payments in Morocco and for purchases from the Bank Al-Maghrib of convertible currencies. Foreign transfers between Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams may be made freely, and there are no restrictions on the interest rate payable. Holders of these accounts may obtain international credit cards with which to settle their bills in Morocco and abroad. 3. Payments Agreement Accounts are held by the Bank Al-Maghrib for central banks (or similar institutions) of the countries with which Morocco maintains bilateral payments agreements (see footnote 3); they are used only for settlements with these countries, including settlements for imports and exports. 4. Capital Accounts, which may be held by any non- resident, are credited with funds that may not be trans- ferred abroad. These include the proceeds from the sale on the Casablanca Stock Exchange of foreign or Moroccan securities without retransfer guarantees and proceeds from the contractual or accelerated redemption of secu- rities quoted on the Casablanca Stock Exchange and lacking retransfer guarantees. Transfers between Capital Accounts related to countries in the area of convertibility or the same country in the payments agreement group are permitted freely. Capital Accounts may be debited freely for purchases of specified government bonds and for personal expenses of the account holder and his immediate relatives during visits to Morocco (subject to a limit of DH 30,000 a Gregorian calendar year for each account regardless of the number of beneficiaries or of journeys made by them to Morocco. However, at the request of the parties concerned, the Exchange Office is prepared to grant higher limits, upon presentation of specific requests giving fu ll details of the nature of the expenditure to be incurred in Morocco). 5. Suspense Accounts are used for holding nonresident funds not available for credit to any of the accounts mentioned above. Balances on these accounts may be used freely to pay taxes due in Morocco, and up to DH 30,000 a year, to pay the costs of the stay in Morocco of the account holder, the spouse, or other immediate relatives; but all other debits to these accounts require approval. 6. Two Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams are held by the Bank Al-Maghrib for the Central Bank of Tunisia and the Central Bank of Mauritania; at present, 6 Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams may be credited w i th d i rham proceeds from the surrender of foreign bank notes, upon presentation of the original customs declaration ju s t i fy ing the importation of the foreign exchange surrendered. 344 only the account of the Central Bank of Tunisia is operational. Imports and Import Payments Imports are admitted in accordance with an annual General Import Program, divided into two categories and applicable to all countries. Goods on List A may be imported freely. For a large number of goods on List B, quotas are not established, and imports are approved according to need, licenses usually being issued upon application (SB items). To import goods in List A, the importer signs an import commitment (engagement a"im- portation), which does not require administrative approval unless the goods are imported from a coun try other than that of origin or are purchased on a c.i.f. basis;7 but for goods in List B, an import certificate (autorisation a"im- portation or certificat d'importation) must be obtained. Cereals, sugar, tea, and fertilizers are imported by official agencies. For all imports the import title —import certificate or import comm i tmen t —must be domiciled (registered) with an authorized bank, wh ich may make paymen ts upon submission of the required documen ts. Import certificates require the visa of the Exchange Office before the foreign exchange is made available. Import comm i tmen ts require this visa only when the coun try of origin and the country of shipment of the goods concerned d iffer or when imports are contracted for on a c.i.f. basis. Special procedures are applicable to specified imports financed by foreign aid or loans. Imports used for the production of export goods can be financed directly from the proceeds of foreign exchange claims of the same exporter w i th in the framework of special lines of credit that Moroccan com- mercial banks are authorized to contract with their foreign correspondents. At the t ime the import transaction is domiciled w i th an authorized bank, a stamp du ty of DH 50 is levied on import transactions valued at DH 2,000 or more. Payments for Invisibles Paymen ts for most current invisibles require the ap- proval of the Exchange Office, but in several instances the approval authority has been delegated to the banks. The authorized banks are permitted to make payments and settle expenses incidental to the commercial trans- action covered by the relevant import or export docu- ments. Earnings after tax on approved nonresident in- vestments in Morocco are transferable to the investor's country of residence. The transfer of dividends on non- resident-owned shares of Moroccan companies listed on the Casablanca Stock Exchange and having their main office in Morocco is unrestricted; dividend transfer by unlisted companies requires the approval of the Exchange Office. Undistributed profits relating to the financial year 1968 or later remain transferable inde f in i te ly. Some paymen ts are subject to limitations. A foreign 7 C . i .f. imports of List A goods require prior exchange control approval. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution employee may transfer to the employee's country of origin, subject to the initial approval of the Exchange Office, 50 percent of his monthly wages or salary if the spouse does not reside in Morocco, or 30 percent if the employee is single or his family lives in Morocco; teachers attached to the Ministry of National Education are allowed an additional transfer of 35 percent for 30 days' leave taken abroad, 70 percent for 60 days' leave, and 105 percent for 70 days' leave. For the medical or paramedical professions, the assessment of transferable amounts (30 percent or 50 percent, according to whe ther the spouse lives in Morocco) is based on taxable income minus applicable duties and taxes. The same applies to other liberal professions as well as to persons engaged in industry, trade, agriculture, and crafts. For retired persons the calculation of the transferable amount (30 percent or 50 percent) is based on gross pensions. Moroccan residents as well as residents of foreign nationality who do not periodically transfer funds abroad and who wish to travel abroad are entitled to a foreign exchange allocation equivalent to DH 100 a person a year. There is a special allocation for pilgrimages. Resi- dents of foreign nationality may acquire exchange for tourist travel up to the equivalent of DH 2,500 a year for each passport by selling to an authorized bank a corre- sponding amount in foreign exchange (other than bank notes) from their own foreign assets not subject to surrender requirements. Foreign exchange allocation up to the equivalent of DH 2,000 a month is granted to foreign nationals residing in Morocco to cover the cost of higher education for a child s tudy ing abroad. A special tax of DH 100 a person is levied on Moroccan or foreign residents traveling abroad, with the exception of pilgrims, students, emigrant workers, and those trav- eling on official business. For business travel a standard allowance equivalent to DH 1,000 a day is granted, up to DH 10,000 a person a trip and within an annual ceiling fixed individually by the Exchange Office; exporters and professional members of the tourist indus try may obtain up to the equivalent of DH 1,000 a person a day, up to the equivalent of DH 15,000 a trip, within a ceiling of 3 percent of the foreign exchange repatriated during the preceding calendar year. The allocation issued for busi- ness travel may be added to the allocation issued for tourist travel. Moroccan students pursuing higher studies at the first, second, or third level abroad and who do not hold scholarships may obtain monthly allocations of foreign exchange up to the maximum equivalent of DH 3,000. Students holding scholarships are eligible for a supplementary monthly allocation equ iva lent to DH 1,500. Students are entitled to an annual installation allowance equivalent to DH 5,000. There is also a quar- terly allocation of the equivalent of DH 3,600 as a fu r ther supplement for scholarship students. The export of Mo- roccan bank notes is prohibited. Workers leaving Morocco to work abroad for the first time or returning to their workplace abroad may be granted DH 5,000 in foreign bank notes upon presentation of an employment contract. MOROCCO Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports may be made free ly, although export licenses are required for a few items. All f ru i ts, fresh vegetables, raw cotton, and cotton by-products may be exported only either directly by the producers or through a state-trading agency, the Office of Marketing and Export (Office de Commercialisation et d'Exportation—OCE), which is also in charge of wine exports. All exporters must sign an undertaking to repatriate and surrender foreign exchange proceeds. The surrender to the exporter's bank must take place within one month from the date the payment is due. The date on which the payment is due is the maturity date fixed in the commercial contract; in principle, this date must not be set more than 90 days after the date of arrival of the merchandise at the place of destination. When the exporter's bank receives the advice of credit in foreign exchange from abroad, foreign exchange is not automatically surrendered to the Bank Al-Maghrib if it represents the proceeds of mobi- lization of foreign exchange claims arising out of exports. Proceeds from Invisibles Residents of Moroccan nationality and Moroccan com- panies must repatriate exchange receipts accruing from all their noncommercial claims and surrender them to an authorized bank. Other residents must surrender noncom- mercial receipts only if the receipts result from current transactions. Moroccans working abroad must surrender such currencies w i th in one month of re-entry, but are permitted, when leaving again, to repurchase 15 percent of the amount surrendered. The importation of Moroccan bank notes is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may freely bring in foreign bank notes and traveler's checks; foreign currency imported in excess of the equivalent of DH 15,000 mus t, however, be declared to the customs authorities.8 Resident travelers also may bring in foreign bank notes in any amoun t, but these must be surrendered w i th in 30 days of re-entry. Capital Residents of Moroccan nationality, as well as compa- nies established in Morocco, are obligated to declare to the Exchange Office all foreign-held assets exceeding DH 250 and to repatriate and surrender certain of these assets. The disposal of other foreign-held assets requires permission. The transfer of capital abroad by residents must be approved.9 Remittance of the assets of emigrants and transfers in the form of gifts are not normally approved, nor is inves tment by private individuals in foreign securities or real estate. Exchange allocations for the transfer of inheritances are limited to the equivalent of DH 35,000 a beneficiary. Permissible transfers of assets by resident foreigners on final departure are fixed at 8 On January 28, 1988 the requirement to declare and state the source of funds at customs was abolished. 9 W i th effect from March 14, 1988, operations invo lv ing the conveyance of real property located in Morocco and belonging to foreign persons are no longer subject to authorization by the Exchange Office. 345 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO DH 25,000 for each year of stay, with no upper limit on the amount. In the case of resident foreigners leaving Morocco, Capital Accounts and Suspense Accounts with a balance not exceeding DH 100,000 on June 30, 1986 may be transferred in their entirety, provided that the bank has submitted to the Exchange Office requests for approval accompanied by the necessary information con- cerning these accounts before June 30, 1987. A new industrial investment code, which came into force in February 1983, provides for full foreign ownership of Moroccan companies in certain sectors and an easing of repatriation of capital; it also grants fiscal and other incentives for foreign investment. In addition, an invest- ment code introduced for the tourist sector in August 1983 offers tax and other incentives to domestic and foreign investors in most areas of the tourist sector; it also provides for full repatriation of tourist-related profits after tax, without any restraint on timing. Operations through Capital Accounts that may be effected with approval include: (1) purchases on the Casablanca Stock Exchange of Moroccan and non- Moroccan securities; (2) purchases of Moroccan securities not quoted on the Casablanca Stock Exchange or partic- ipation in a Moroccan firm; (3) subscriptions to (2); (4) investments of any kind, including purchases of busi- nesses or office buildings; (5) lending to residents; (6) payment of local expenses in excess of DH 30,000 during the account holder's stay in Morocco; (7) any payments to beneficiaries other than the holder of the account or a close relative; (8) any payments from an account held by a foreign juridical person; (9) gifts to social, cultural, or religious institutions; (10) subscriptions to capital in- creases of Moroccan companies whose shares are quoted on the Casablanca Stock Exchange; (11) subscriptions at the time of issue to long-term or short-term, fixed-yield securities issued by a Moroccan public entity; (12) custody charges and commissions on securities; and (13) payment of the cost of maintenance, repairs, real estate taxes, and insurance on real estate located in Morocco. Subject to approval, Capital Accounts may also be debited for investments in Morocco, within the framework of the 1973 Investment Code, provided that the amounts debited do not exceed 50 percent of the investment undertaken by the nonresident and 25 percent of the company's total capital.10 10 With effect from March 1, 1988, the following types of inves tment have been permitted without the prior authorization of the Exchange Office: (1) participation in the equity capital of a company being estab- lished; (2) subscription to the capital increase of an existing company; (3) purchase of Moroccan securities; (4) non-interest-bearing contributions to partnership current accounts; (5) purchase of real property; (6) self- financing of construction projects; (7) creation or purchase of a sole proprietorship; and (8) operations to increase capital through the capital- ization of reserves, carryovers, or reserve provisions that have become available, or the consolidation of partnership current accounts. Similarly, operations involving the conveyance of inves tmen ts between foreigners no longer require the authorization of the Exchange Office, even in cases 346 Certain government bonds acquired with funds from Capital Accounts are freely negotiable between nonresi- dents. These are 7.5 percent, five-year bonds on which interest and redemption proceeds are transferable. All other transactions in securities involving nonresident interests, as well as the import and export of securities, require approval. Banks are permitted to engage in short- term borrowing abroad; they may accept convertible currency funds from nonresidents for credit to Special Deposit Accounts, provided that these funds are rein- vested abroad in the same currency and for the same maturity period. The rate of interest paid by banks on these deposits may not exceed the rate received by them on their corresponding placements. Gold Commemorative gold coins with a face value of DH 250 and DH 500 have been issued and are legal tender. Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Morocco for numismatic or investment purposes. Ten different types of foreign gold coins are traded on the Casablanca Stock Exchange, which does not, however, deal in gold bars. Imports of gold are subject to autho- rization by the Directorate of Customs and Indirect Taxes. Each year, the Ministry of Finance fixes a quota for the importation of gold ingots, which is then allocated among jewelers and industrial users of precious metals. Exports of gold are prohibited. Not for Redistribution MOZAMBIQUE (Position on December 31, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Mozambique is the Metical (plural Meticais). E f fec t ive January 31, 1987, the peg to a basket of six currencies was suspended and the metical was pegged to the U.S. dollar. At the same time, the exchange rate was adjusted from Mt. 38.279 = US$1 (buy ing) and Mt. 39.069 - US$1 (selling) to Mt. 200 - US$1 (buying) and Mt. 204 - US$1 (selling). With effect from June 27, 1987, the exchange rates of the metical were adjusted to Mt. 400 - US$1 (buying) and Mt. 408 = US$1 (selling).1 Exchange rates for 20 other currencies are published daily by the Bank of Mozambique .2 There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. Administration of Control The National Planning Commission prepares annually, in consultation w i th central and provincial government agencies, a foreign exchange budget for the following year, as part of the Central State Plan. Imports and exports are authorized by means of licenses, within limits and on the basis of priorities established in the foreign exchange budget. Foreign exchange transactions, includ- ing the surrender of foreign exchange proceeds, are effected through the Bank of Mozambique, which is both the central bank and the only bank w i th external banking func t ions. Arrears are maintained with respect to external paymen ts. Prescription of Currency Mozambique has bilateral paymen ts agreements with Tanzania and the German Democratic Republic. Bilateral agreements containing bilateral clearing arrangement fea- tures are maintained with Malawi, Swaziland, and Zimbabwe. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents in Mozambique can hold foreign exchange accounts in the Bank of Mozambique. There is no re- striction on the use of these accounts. Nonresidents in Mozambique under work contracts and having income in national currency that is earned from providing services under work contracts may hold national currency ac- counts in any bank operating in the coun try. There is no restriction on the use of these accounts. Persons or businesses residing abroad may request to open nonres- ident bank accounts for purposes based on legitimate interests they retain in Mozambique; credits and debits to these accounts must comply with the regulations 1 With effect from January 1, 1988, the exchange rates of the metical were adjusted to Mt. 450 = US$1 (buy ing) and Mt. 459 = US$1 (selling). 2 Austrian schilling, Belgian franc, Canadian dollar, Danish krone, deutsche mark, Finnish markka, French franc, Italian lira, Japanese yen, Malawi kwacha, Netherlands guilder, Norwegian krone, Portuguese es- cudo, pound sterling, South African rand, Spanish peseta, Swedish krona, Swiss franc, Zambian kwacha, and Zimbabwe dollar. established by the competent authorities. Ex-residents (nationals and foreigners who no longer enjoy residency status) may hold bank accounts in Mozambique, but their use is subject to prior authorization, in accordance with Ministry of Finance regulations; drawings may be made by the holders of such accounts for payment of taxes, a certain type of debt, maintenance of spouses or relatives, expenses while visiting the country, and other payments within the country. Imports and Import Payments All imports are subject to licensing, within limits es- tablished in the State Central Plan. In accordance with their objective, state trading enterprises can license them- selves for transactions within these limits. The license specifies the place of embarkation or disembarkation of the goods and the amount and currency of payment. Other enterprises may obtain import licenses from the Ministry of Commerce, which considers applications on a case-by-case basis. Imports of raw materials, parts and spare parts, petroleum, food, and medicines are given priority. Individuals may obtain import licenses for up to US$500 for personal use if expenditures from the coun- try's foreign exchange fund are not involved. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are processed by the Bank of Mozambique upon presentation of the authorization granted by the Ministry of Finance. Allowances for travel are made available to individuals only in certain cases, mainly for medical treatment purposes. Each Ministry receives an allocation to be used for business travel and educational travel expenses. Foreign experts working in Mozambique may remit abroad a percentage of their salaries, depending on the salary level. Nonresidents may export foreign bank notes up to the amount declared on entry. Exports and reimports of domestic currency are limited to Mt. 500 a person leaving the country temporarily for the purpose of meeting incidental expenses on return. Citizens leaving the country on business and private travel are entitled to purchase foreign currency at the border up to the equivalent of US$12.50 once a year. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports are subject to licensing, and all export proceeds must be collected through the- Bank of Mozam- bique. Export licenses are granted if applicable legal requirements are fulfilled. Exporters of traditional prod- ucts (cashew, cotton, copra, tea, sugar, and citrus) are allowed to retain a percentage of foreign exchange pro- ceeds for purchases of imported inputs. Since the begin- ning of 1987, exporters of nontraditional products have also become eligible to participate in the system. 347 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOZAMBIQUE Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to the Bank of Mozambique. Capital The Government, the Bank of Mozambique, and en- terprises are authorized to borrow abroad. All foreign borrowing is channeled through the Bank of Mozambique, which registers and guarantees such loans. The Direct Foreign Investment Law, published in April 1984, aims to encourage the participation of foreign capital both in the formation of new enterprises with exclusively foreign capital and in association with other Mozambican enter- prises. For this purpose, a Foreign Investment Promotion Office was established in 1984. The Direct Foreign In- vestment Law specifies guarantees to investors as well as the right to transfer invested capital and a portion of profits abroad. The incentives for foreign investments include tax and customs exemptions for specified periods of time and access to domestic credit. Gold There are no legal limitations on gold acquisitions. Imports of gold jewelry or other precious metals are governed by special regulations. Changes During 1987 Exchange Arrangement January 31. Not for Redistribution NEPAL (Position on December 31, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Nepal is the Nepalese Rupee, the exchange rate of which fluctuates on the basis of a currency basket. On December 31,1987 the official buying and selling rates were NRs 21.50 and NRs 21.70, respec- tively, per US$1. Buying and selling rates are quoted daily for certain other currencies,1 with quotations based on the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in markets abroad. Only buying rates are quoted for Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Italian lire, Danish kroner, Swedish kronor, Hong Kong dollars, and Saudi Arabian rivals, based on buying rates for the U.S. dollar in markets abroad. Residents may freely purchase Indian rupees from Nepalese banks, and they may hold any amount of Indian notes and coin. The Nepal Rastra Bank guarantees free and unlimited convertibility between Indian and Nepalese rupees; however, Indian rupees are not legal tender in Nepal. Forward exchange cover is available only in U.S. dollars for export transactions. Administration of Control Permission is required from the Ministry of Finance for all payments in convertible currencies except for import payments and certain other specified payments. The licensing of imports from countries other than India is administered by the Department of Commerce. Each government ministry receives an allocation under the foreign exchange budget. The licensing of exports of most goods to countries other than India is also the responsi- bility of the Ministry of Commerce. All exchange trans- actions with countries other than India must be settled through authorized dealers (the Nepal Bank Ltd ., Nepal Arab Bank, Nepal Grindlay's Bank, Indo Suez Bank, and the Rastriya Banijya Bank). Nonbank authorized dealers are licensed to purchase foreign currencies; any sale of such currencies other than Indian rupees is subject to the prior approval of the Nepal Rastra Bank. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements apply to outgoing payments to countries with which no payments agreement is in force,2 and these may be made in foreign currency supplied by the Nepal Rastra Bank. All current transactions with member countries of the Asian Clearing Union (ACU) other than India (Bangladesh, Burma, the Islamic Republic of Iran, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka) must be effected through the ACU. Payments for imports from India are settled in Indian rupees. The proceeds of exports 1 Australian dollars, Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Indian rupees, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and Singapore dollars. 2 Nepal maintains bilateral paymen ts agreements with Bulgaria, Czech- oslovakia, Poland, and the U.S.S.R.; payments for transactions under the agreement with Poland are settled through a special account in pounds sterling. to India are obtained in Indian rupees, while proceeds from other countries must be received in any of the quoted convertible currencies for which the Nepal Rastra Bank quotes buying and selling rates. Foreign Currency Accounts Commercial banks may accept deposits denominated in U.S. dollars and pounds sterling and determine the rate of interest on such deposits. Eligibility for the opening of such accounts is limited to (1) Nepalese citizens earning convertible foreign currency from employment in inter- national organizations, agencies, or embassies; (2) Ne- palese citizens earning foreign currency by working abroad (except in India and Bhutan) for more than six months; (3) international organizations and foreign nationals; and (4) Indian and Bhutanese citizens residing in countries other than Nepal, India, or Bhutan. Current and time deposit accounts can be opened, the latter for periods of three months, six months, nine months, or one year. Current accounts may be opened with a minimum of US$1,000 (or the equivalent), and time deposits with a m in imum of US$5,000 (or the equivalent). Nonresidents can withdraw their deposits at any time, and these can be converted into any convertible currency at the com- mercial banks. In the case of Nepalese citizens returning from overseas, foreign currency accounts have to be surrendered for local currency within one year of return to Nepal. Before that time limit expires, 70 percent of the local currency value of the deposit can be exchanged for import licenses in the same value and the remainder can be exchanged for local currency. Nonresident Accounts The Nepal Rastra Bank permits nonresidents to open "convertible rupee accounts" with Nepalese banks; bal- ances on these accounts may be freely transferred abroad. Accounts in Indian currency may be opened only under special arrangements. Foreign currencies brought into or received in Nepal by nonresidents, which are converted into Nepalese rupees and deposited with a Nepalese bank, can be reconverted for transfer out of the country, subject to prior permission of the Nepal Rastra Bank. Imports and Import Payments Imports from India do not require import licenses. All other imports require import licenses and are subject to quantitative restrictions, except imports under baggage rules. Imports of certain items, such as cigarettes and matches, goods considered harmful for health, arms, ammunition and explosives, wireless transmitters, pre- cious metals, and jewelry (except under baggage rule), require special permission of the Government. Imports of several items, including beef, washing soap (except from India), and detergent powder, are banned. Under the Trade and Transit Treaties, Nepal and India have 349 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NEPAL agreed to freedom of trade between themselves in Ne- palese and Indian goods; Indian goods may, in principle, be imported freely (although some are subject to a permit system in order to prevent their re-exportation, and certain others are subject to export ceilings in India). Reimburse- ment of tax is made by the Government of India to the Government of Nepal on direct imports from Indian manufacturers of products subject to excise du ty in India. Under a new system intended to simplify procedures for the importation of industrial raw materials from countries other than India and to reduce uncertainty about their availability, entrepreneurs may apply for a passbook. They receive entitlements for importers' inputs (in the form of a passbook for a period of one year) based on the previous year's production level and the current year's production program, with the possibility of their renewal after expiration. The total value of the passbook may be adjusted in case of changes in capacity. Import licenses are automatically issued against these entitlements. In addition to the passbook system, imports of 26 items, mainly raw materials and intermediary goods, are im- ported under the Open General Licensing system (OGL). Import licenses are also auctioned for specified goods. The total value of import licenses to be auctioned depends on the available amount of foreign exchange. Foreign exchange is automatically provided to successful bidders at the official exchange rate. A fee of 1 percent of the value of the license is imposed for all imports, including import licenses that are auc- tioned, with the exception of personal imports for which the license fee varies according to the goods to be imported and source of finance. Margin deposits are required on letters of credit as follows: (1) 10 percent for industrial raw materials, machinery, and spare parts, if imported by registered industries or allied trading enterprises; (2) 30 percent for development and construction materials (such as cement, iron and iron rods, and corrugated sheets), dairy products, writing papers, new print, agri- cultural goods, medical equipment, and educational and scientific materials; and (3) 50 percent for all other imports. Nepalese citizens returning from abroad who have spent at least seven nights out of the country are allowed to bring in goods worth NRs 1,000, free of customs duties and sales taxes. In addition, they can import, without license but subject to customs duties and taxes, special goods worth up to NRs 15,000 twice a year. For those who have official sources of foreign exchange earnings and have stayed abroad for more than one month, addi- tional imports are allowed. Payments for Invisibles Payments to India may be made freely in Indian rupees, but for amounts of NRs 500 or over, the purpose of the payment must be declared. For travel to countries other than India for medical treatment, exchange allowance is granted as recom- mended by a panel of doctors. Students studying at their own expense in these countries are granted exchange allowance covering expenses for boarding, lodging, and 350 tuition fees on the recommendation of the Ministry of Education. Foreign exchange is made available for certain business trips, but is restricted for tourist travel abroad. Payments for other invisibles depend on the essentiality of the transaction and availability of foreign exchange. Nepalese and Indian currencies may be taken out freely to India only by Nepalese and Indian nationals; the export of these currencies to countries other than India is prohibited. Foreign bank notes, other than Indian bank notes, may not be taken out by residents without per- mission. Nonresidents may take out the unchanged amount of any foreign bank notes they brought in; however, nonresidents, other than Indian nationals, may not take out Nepalese or Indian bank notes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of items having archaeological and religious importance (such as ancient statues, paintings, and coins) and certain other products including gold, silver, gold and silver coins, diamonds, jewelry made of gold or diamonds, wild animals, musk and musk deer, snake and lizard skins, narcotics, explosive materials, chemicals for ammun i t ion, raw skin and wool, Coca-Cola, logs and sawn wood, and other specified items are prohibited. The re-export to India of non-Nepalese goods is not permitted, and re-export to any destination of goods imported from India is prohibited. Export licenses are not required, with the exception of a few specified goods, the exportation of which is quan t i ta t ive ly restricted or prohibited. The exchange proceeds from exports, except Indian rupees, must be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or to an authorized bank w i th in six months after shipment. Unit values are defined on an f.o.b. basis. Exports of ju te, ju te goods, rice, turmeric, catechu, oil cake, food- grains, pulses, processed and semiprocessed leather, woolen carpet, and ready-made garments to countries other than India in excess of US$1,000 in value are allowed only against irrevocable letters of credit. Foreign tourists leaving Nepal may take out as sou- venirs, without permission, Nepalese goods whose value does not exceed the value of foreign currency exchanged in Nepal. Commercial banks may grant pre-export credit of up to 70 percent of the f.o.b. value of products specified by the Government to all individuals and institutions holding irrevocable letters of credit opened or endorsed by foreign banks acceptable to the Nepalese banks. Such credit may be provided for a maximum period of three mon ths; this period may be extended without penalties under special circumstances outside the control of the exporter. Proceeds from Invisibles With the exception of Indian rupees, foreign exchange proceeds derived from transactions in invisibles must be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or an authorized bank at the official rate of exchange. Nepalese and Indian currency may be brought in only from India, and only by Nepalese and Indian nationals; the import of these cur- rencies from countries other than India is prohibited. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution When extending their visas, tourists are required to produce evidence that they have converted a m in imum of US$5 at the official rate of exchange for each day's stay. Nonresidents other than Indian nationals are not allowed to bring in Nepalese or Indian bank notes. Other foreign bank notes may be brought in freely by residents and nonresidents, but they must be declared. Capital No conditions are specified concerning receipts and remittances in respect of capital transactions, but official exchange is not normally provided for capital remittances by Nepalese nationals. Nepalese citizens, whether resi- deot in Nepal or not, are prohibited from making any type of investment in foreign countries, except inves tment specifically exempted by government notice; the exemp- tions include the purchase and sale of insurance policies abroad, investments abroad by any banking or financial institution incorporated in Nepal, and the purchase of shares of foreign companies under a rights issue. Foreign investors who have obtained an investment guarantee are eligible for outward remittances in respect of the following items: all or part of the sales proceeds of investment, dividends, interest, or principal repayment, amounts arising from the transfer of technology, and compensations on acquired assets. In the case of proceeds of investment sales and dividends, remittances may be subject to installments fixed by the Government. NEPAL Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Nepal. Imports of gold are banned, except under baggage rules. Changes During 1987 Imports and Import Payments January 28. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS (Position on December 31, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of the Netherlands is the Netherlands Guilder. The Netherlands participates with Belgium, Den- mark, France, the Federal Republic of Germany, Ireland, Italy, and Luxembourg in the exchange rate and inter- vention mechanism of the European Monetary System (EMS). In accordance with this agreement, the Nether- lands maintains the spot exchange rates between the Netherlands guilder and the currencies of the other participants within margins of 2.25 percent (in the case of the Italian lira, 6 percent) above or below the cross rates based on the central rates expressed in European Currency Units (ECUs). The agreement implies that the Netherlands Bank stands ready to buy or sell the currencies of the other participating states in unlimited amounts at specified intervention rates. On December 31, 1987 these rates were as follows: Specified Intervention Rates Per: 100 Belgian or Luxembourg francs 100 Danish kroner 100 deutsche mark 100 French francs 1 Irish pound 10,000 Italian lire Netherlands Guilders Upper limit Lower limit 5.5870 30.2100 115.2350 34.3600 3.0870 16.600 5.3415 28.8825 110.1675 32.8475 2.9510 14.725 The participants in the EMS do not maintain exchange rates for other currencies within fixed limits. However, in order to ensure a proper functioning of the system, they intervene in concert to smooth out fluctuations in exchange rates, the intervention currencies being each other's and the U.S. dollar. The authorized banks quote buying and selling rates for 15 foreign currencies and the ECU .1 On Decem- ber 31, 1987 the authorized banks' buying and selling rates were f. 1.77625 and f. 1.77875, respectively, per US$1. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. Authorized banks are freely permitted to buy and sell convertible and inconvertible currencies, both spot and forward; they are free to deal with residents and nonres- idents, whether banks or nonbanks. Forward exchange contracts are not limited as to delivery period, nor is an underlying trade transaction required. Nonbank residents are free to hold foreign currency accounts in the Netherlands. 1 Aus t r ian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish k rone r, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Italian lire, Irish pounds, Japanese yen, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 352 The Kingdom of the Netherlands formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Exchange Control Territory Transactions with the Netherlands Antilles are subject to the same exchange controls as transactions with other countries. With regard to any third countries with which paymen ts agreements might be in force, the Netherlands and the Netherlands Antilles will, if so stipulated, con- s t i tu te the Ne ther lands Monetary Area. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Netherlands Bank on behalf of the Ministers of Foreign Affairs, Finance, Economic Affa irs, and Agriculture. Import and export licensing, including transit trade,2 is handled by the Central Import-Export Agency (CDIU) and the delegated offices, under directives from the Directorate- General for Foreign Economic Relations. For their paymen ts to and receipts from nonresidents in the Ne ther lands, residents are generally required to use the intermediation of banks or other domestic institutions or persons authorized by the Ne ther lands Bank to handle these exchange transactions w i th in the scope of the regulations based on the External Financial Relations Act 1980 (see section on Capital, below). To facilitate the compilation of the balance of paymen ts, residents are required to indicate on reporting forms, for all payments to and receipts from nonres iden ts exceeding f. 5,000, the nature of the unde r ly ing transaction as well as the currency and amount paid or received. Separate regulations govern the reporting of settlements where no transfer of money is invo lved. Residents are free to open and maintain bank accounts abroad and to maintain current accounts abroad for the purpose of settlements. The Netherlands Bank must be notified of such accounts, and entries in them are to be reported to the Bank in accordance with the related regulations. Prescription of Currency In effec t ing paymen ts to nonresidents or collecting receipts from them, residents may make use of guilders or any foreign currency. Payments in any foreign currency between residents may be made freely. There are no bilateral paymen ts agreements in force. Nonresidents are free to open and maintain nonres ident accounts w i th authorized banks in the Netherlands in guilders or in any foreign currency, and to effect paymen ts to, or collect receipts f rom, res iden ts. All paymen ts or receipts are free ly pe rm i t ted, as well as transfers of balances to and from other nonres ident accounts. 2 The on ly t rans it trade transactions s t i ll sub ject to specific license are purchases and sales of strategic goods. ©International Monetary Fund.
