Not for Redistribution URUGUAY (Position on December 31, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Uruguay is the Uruguayan New Peso. Uruguay follows a floating exchange rate policy under which the exchange rate of the Uruguayan new peso is determined by market forces, although the Central Bank reserves the right, in principle, to intervene for the purpose of preventing disorderly conditions in the exchange mar- ket. Buying and selling interbank rates for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, on December 31, 1987 were NUr$279.5 and NUr$281.0, respectively, per US$1. Rates for other currencies are based on U.S. dollar rates in exchange markets abroad. A tax of 1.5 percent is levied on sales of foreign exchange in both the spot and forward exchange markets, if a transaction is settled in Uruguayan new pesos; the tax rate is 0.3 percent for sales of foreign exchange through interbank operations. Export proceeds are required to be sold to the com- mercial banks. There are no limits on the amount of foreign exchange that the Central Bank may sell to or buy from the Bank of the Republic, the Mortgage Bank, commercial banks, and banking and exchange houses. Uruguay formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from May 2, 1980. Administration of Control Exchange transactions are carried out through autho- rized banks, banking houses, exchange houses, and the Bank of the Republic. Any person or firm may conduct exchange transactions in the market. Exchange houses must be authorized by the Central Bank. Prescription of Currency Payments between Uruguay and the countries with which Uruguay has concluded reciprocal credit agree- ments may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the central banks, within the framework of the multilateral clearing system of the Latin American Integration Association (LAIA); these countries are Ar- gentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Mex- ico, Paraguay, Peru, and Venezuela. There are separate arrangements for trade in specified goods with Argentina, Brazil, and Mexico, among other countries. All settle- ments are made in U.S. dollars or other convertible currencies. Imports and Import Payments All imports are subject to registration before the goods are shipped. The registrations are generally valid for 180 days, within which period goods must be cleared through customs. Most imports are subject to import surcharges. The surcharge rates are within a range of 10-45 percent and are payable to the Bank of the Republic at the time of registration. Full or partial exemption from these sur- charges is granted for imports from member countries of the LAI A, imports of agricultural inputs, imports by the public sector, imports of machinery., equipment, tools, and spare parts for certain priority industries, and imports under the temporary admission scheme. The Bank of the Republic also collects a consular charge of 4 percent on the f.o.b. value of certain imports. Most imports are also subject to a customs tariff (impuesto aduanero unico, IMADUN I) and a service charge (tasa de movilizacion de bultos, TMB), collected by the Customs Office. Tariff rates vary between zero and 15 percent. The service charge is 1 percent of the c.i.f. import price for most imports. There are exemptions to IMADUNI and TMB. The combined effective tariff rate (including surcharges, tariffs, consular fees, and service charges) is limited to a maximum of 45 percent. Import surcharges, IMADUNI, and TMB are calculated either on an officially assessed price (precio de referenda), on a minimum export price, or on the actual c.i.f. value, whichever is the highest. Payments for Invisibles There are no limitations on the export of foreign or domestic bank notes. Exports and Export Proceeds Foreign exchange proceeds from exports must be sold to the banks not later than 36 months after the expiration date of shipping documents. Exporters are eligible for rebates in respect of indirect taxes paid during the production process; these rebates replaced the system of tax credit certificates with effect from January 1, 1983. From time to time, and for special reasons (e.g., stock position, protection, or sanitary considerations), certain exports are forbidden or subjected to special conditions. Traditional exports, such as meat (mutton, beef, and horse), greasy wool (scoured and semiscoured), dry, salted, and pickled hides, and livestock on the hoof (except that of pedigree or pure crossbred), are subject to an export tax at the rate of 5 percent. Fish exports are eligible for tax credit certificates amounting to between 2 percent and 8 percent of the f.o.b. value of exports, which can be used by the exporter to pay taxes or social security contributions, or can be sold to a third party. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no surrender requirements on the proceeds from invisibles, and there are no limitations on the import of foreign or domestic bank notes. Capital Inward and outward private capital transfers by either residents or nonresidents may be made freely, with the 507 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY exception of certain inward and outward transfers relating to investments registered under the Foreign Investment Law. The amortization or liquidation proceeds of foreign capital registered under this law cannot normally be transferred abroad until three years after the date on which the investment was approved. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Uruguay or abroad. Changes During 1987 Imports and Import Payments August 26. The combined effective tariff rates (including surcharges, tariffs, consular charges, and service charges) were reduced, with a few exceptions, from 50 percent to 45 percent, from 45 percent to 40 percent, and from 35 percent to 30 percent. September 3. The official reference prices for textile products were reduced by 10 percent. Exports and Export Proceeds January 29-30. Exporters of leather goods, certain vegetable extracts, and beef and mutton extracts became eligible for rebates of indirect taxes. April 1. A system of registration for meat processors and exporters establishing minimum technical standards entered into effect. June 1. Exporters of citrus fruits became eligible for rebates of indirect taxes. June 17. The rates of incentive payments to fish exporters were lowered from a range of 3-11 percent to 2-8 percent. November 17. Exports of frozen and corned mutton became eligible for rebates of indirect taxes, and exports of live sheep were permitted. 508 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VANUATU (Position on December 31, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Vanua tu is the Va tu, pegged to the SDR at a rate of VT 142 = SDR 1. The Central Bank of Vanuatu buys and sells foreign exchange, and it quotes on a daily basis the rates of the va tu against Australian dollars, French francs, deutsche mark, Japanese yen, and New Zealand dollars on the basis of their respective values in terms of the SDR. The Central Bank deals with the commercial banks in Australian dollars, French francs, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars only. Buying and selling rates are quoted on the basis of 0.375 percent on each side of a middle rate, bu t, in practice, transactions are conducted on the basis of a narrower spread. The Central Bank buys or sells foreign exchange only in transactions with the commercial banks for account of the Government or for its own operations. On December 31, 1987 the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar (for telegraphic transfers) were VT 99.39 and VT 101.58 per US$1, respectively. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. Vanuatu formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from December 1, 1982. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency requirements. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts of residents and nonresidents. Debits and credits to all accounts may be made freely. Imports and Import Payments With the exception of the following, all items may be freely imported: any goods that are controlled under internal legislation in the interest of national health and well-being, such as arms and ammunitions, explosives, and dangerous drugs; certain plants, foodstuffs, and animals, which are also restricted and subject to autho- rization. Importation of cement, canned soft drinks, T-shirts bearing a Vanuatu motif, frozen chickens, and chicken pieces are controlled, either by absolute prohi- bition or by import licensing restriction. Import duties are levied mainly on an ad valorem basis on import values (c.i.f.). Certain high revenue goods, however, are liable to specific rates of import du ty levied on units of quan t i ty (in particular, spirits, wine, beer, tobacco products, and hydrocarbon oils). Imported goods that compete with locally produced equivalents are gen- erally liable to high duty rates. A 5 percent service tax is payable on most imported goods based on the duty- inclusive import value. Goods imported for a specific end-use, particularly those imported for projects likely to aid national, social, or economic development, may be approved for duty- free or duty- and tax-free importation by virtue of one of a number of statutory exemptions. Included in these are goods imported for sale to tourists, ships stores (including fuels), goods imported for processing and re-exportation, and goods imported for investment projects. Payments for Invisibles There are no restrictions on payments for invisibles. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange proceeds from surrendered. invisibles need not be Exports and Export Proceeds With a few exceptions, no restrictions are applied on exports. Exports of trochus, green snails, beches-de-mer, and crustaceans1 are subject to authorization by the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries, and Forestry. Copra and cocoa exports are channeled through the Vanua tu Commodities Marketing Board (VCMB), and exports of coffee are subject to authorization from the VCMB. Artifacts that are five years old or more are subject to authorization from the Cultural Center. Most exports are subject to export duties, mainly on an ad valorem basis (f .o .b .); specific duties are levied on some minor exports, including scrap metal and timber. There are no surrender requirements for export proceeds. Capital All inward and outward movements of capital are unrestricted. Gold There are no restrictions on gold transactions. Changes During 1987 No significant changes occurred in the exchange and trade system. 1 Including coconut crabs for conservation purposes. 509 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA (Position on December 31, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Venezuela is the Venezuelan Bolivar. Venezuela maintains a four-tier exchange rate system under which three of the exchange rates are pegged to the U.S. dollar and the fourth is a fluctuating rate. In the first market the Central Bank sells foreign exchange to the public in eligible cases at the rate of Bs 4.30 = US$1. The Central Bank may also sell foreign exchange at Bs 4.2925 = US$1 to banks, which may in tu rn sell to their customers at a rate of Bs 4.30 = US$1. Eligible payments at this preferential rate include those for (1) interest on private external debt authorized by the Dif- ferential Exchange System Office (RECADI) that fell due before December 31, 1983; (2) amortization of authorized and registered private external debt (defined as net liability position) eligible for immediate payment;1 and (3) amor- tization of 10 percent of debts other than those eligible for immediate payment. In the second market the Central Bank sells foreign exchange to the public at the rate of Bs 7.50 = US$1, and to banks at the rate of Bs 7.4925 = US$1 when the banks act as intermediaries, for the purpose of: (1) interest payments on external private sector debt registered at RECADI and falling due between December 31, 1983 and December 8, 1986; (2) current expenditure and capital expenditure abroad by the public authorities and public sector entities; (3) expenditure derived from the inter- national commitments of the Republic; (4) external public debt interest and amortization payments charged against the budget for fiscal year 1986; (5) external debt servicing of public enterprises, provided the debtor subscribes to the exchange guarantee scheme; (6) amortization pay- ments on registered private external debt other than those eligible for the Bs 4.30 per US$1 rate,2 and interest on private registered debt falling due after December 8, 1986, provided the debtor subscribes to the optional exchange guarantee scheme introduced in December 1986; (7) imports of ''essential" foods tuffs, medicines, and inpu ts for agriculture, clothing, and paper products (including 1 Debts amoun t ing to US$500,000 or less, export credits w i th foreign official guarantee due prior to Ju ly 17, 1986, and debts in the form of certificates of deposit or foreign currency deposits. Debts of between US$500,000 and US$1 m i l l ion, although eligible for immediate paymen t, are to be amortized at the rate of Bs 7.50 per US$1. Export credits w i th foreign official guarantee due after Ju ly 17, 1986 can be amortized at the rate of Bs 7.50 per US$1 on the ir respective dates of m a tu r i ty, if the debtor subscribes to the optional foreign exchange guarantee scheme, except for the amounts fa l l ing due af ter Ju ly 17, 1986 but prior to the signing of a contract between the debtor and the Central Bank, in wh ich case amortization paymen ts can be made immediately at Bs 7.50 per US$1. Amortization paymen ts of pr iva te debts that have been assumed by the Government as guarantor are also effected at the rate of BS 7.50 per US$1. 2 I.e., debts of between US$500,000 and US$1 m i l l ion, export credits w i th off ic ial guarantee falling due after Ju ly 17, 1986 and the date of the signing of the contracts between the debtor and the Central Bank, and 90 percent of the debts covered previously under the five-year rescheduling scheme, provided the debtor subscribes to the optional guarantee scheme introduced in December 1986. 510 related freight and insurance); and (8) most outward remittances to students (until December 31, 1987). In the third market the Central Bank buys foreign exchange at the rate of Bs 14.4925 = US$1 from the public and public sector entities for the proceeds from exports of goods and services (excluding tourism) and all public and registered private capital imports; it sells foreign exchange in the same market to the public at the rate of Bs 14.50 = US$1, and to banks at the rate of Bs 14.4925 = US$1 when the banks act as intermediaries, for the purpose of: (1) all imports of goods and services (excluding tourism) other than those eligible for the Bs 7.50 per US$1 rate; (2) public sector current payments abroad and paymen ts related to international commit- ments of the Government of Venezuela; (3) outward remittances to certain students abroad during 1987, and to all students abroad after December 31, 1987; (4) interest and amortization paymen ts on external debt contracted or serviced by the Central Governmen t; and (5) private debt amortization payments on registered debts eligible for but not covered by the optional exchange rate guar- antee scheme. In the four th market transactions take place at a freely fluctuating rate; this rate applies to tourism transactions and nonregistered private capital flows. The Central Bank may buy and sell foreign exchange at the fluctuating rate market, which operates through financial intermediaries. The banks and exchange houses in this market may establish different exchange rates according to the instru- ment being transacted, but the spread between buying and selling rates for the same ins trument may not exceed Bs 0.05 per US$1 in the case of banks, and Bs 0.15 per US$1 in the case of exchange houses. On December 31, 1987 the buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar at the foreign exchange houses were Bs 30.40 = US$1 and Bs 30.50 = US$1, respectively. Buy ing and selling rates for other officially quoted currencies3 are based, for each market, on the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in major markets abroad. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. In the case of interbank transfers, domestic banks may charge only the cost of the transfer, including commission and other charges by the foreign banks. Under the exchange rate guarantee scheme, debt- ors can acquire guaranteed access to foreign exchange at the rate of Bs 7.50 per US$1 by paying a premium (see section on Capital, below). As regards import operations using foreign exchange from the official market, cover is available as follows: (1) if the operation is covered by letters of credit, the exchange rate applicable for paying for the import will be the rate prevailing when the letter of credit is opened, provided no more than 360 days have 3 Canadian dollars, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Portuguese escudos, pounds s ter l ing, Spanish pesetas, and Swiss francs. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution elapsed since the date on which the letter of credit was opened; (2) if the operation is carried out using facilities other than a letter of credit, the exchange rate applicable for the payment will be the rate prevailing on the date of shipment of the goods or, if the goods have not been shipped, on the date the legal documentation is issued attesting to the commitment assumed by the importer; (3) if the imports are effected in cash, the exchange rate applicable to the payment will be maintained for a period of 180 days from the date of shipment of the merchandise; and (4) if the import is financed with suppliers' credits, the exchange rate applicable to the transfer will be maintained for 360 consecutive days from the date of shipment of the merchandise. Venezuela formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, on July 1, 1976. Administration of Control Foreign exchange policies are established by the Min- istry of Finance, with the advice of the Differential Exchange System Advisory Committee. The committee is chaired by the Minister of Finance and includes the Minister of Development, the Minister of Agriculture and Livestock, the Minister of the Central Coordination and Planning Office, the President of the Central Bank of Venezuela, and the President of the Venezuelan Invest- ment Fund. The exchange control system is administered by the Central Bank and the Ministry of Finance. Import and export licenses are generally issued by the Ministry of Development or the Ministry of Agriculture and Live- stock, depending on the commodity. Import quotas and prohibitions within the multiple exchange rate system are established by the Ministry of Finance. The Superinten- dency of Foreign Investments (SIEX) exercises super- vision over foreign investment in Venezuela, over con- tracts for the importation of foreign technology and the use of foreign patents and trademarks, and over borrowing abroad. Arrears are maintained with respect to external payments. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Payments between Venezuela and Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Jamaica, Mexico, Peru, and Uruguay may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the Central Bank of Venezuela and the central banks of the countries concerned. Imports and Import Payments Imports from South Africa are prohibited. In addition, importation of certain goods is either prohibited or re- served for the Government; these include iron and steel products, luxury food, apparel, and specified consumer durables. Certain other commodities also require import licenses. For protective purposes, quantitative restric- tions are maintained on some of these items, irrespective of origin, except in the case of Andean Pact and Latin VENEZUELA America Integration Association (LAIA) member coun- tries. Licenses are valid for all countries except South Africa. Import licenses for some goods are issued on evidence that the importer has purchased domestic prod- ucts equal to a prescribed percentage of the quantity to be imported. Payments for imports of food, medicines, clothing, paper products, and agricultural inputs may be made at the rate of Bs 7.50 = US$1. All other goods that are not prohibited, reserved for the public sector, or subject to special regimes may be imported at the rate of Bs 14.50 = US$1 when authorized by RECADI, or at the free market rate. To have access to foreign exchange from the Central Bank for payment of imports, an importer must obtain an import license (conformidad de importa- tion) from the Directorate of Imports and the Ministry of Finance before the date of shipment of the goods; the license has a validity of 180 days, and may be renewed up to a period determined by the Directorate in each specific case. Import licenses are granted on the basis of semiannual import programs, which are approved for each individual firm at the beginning of each year. In the case of imports channeled through the official market and not effected through a letter of credit, im- porters must submit the import license to the Central Bank within 90 banking days from the date of customs clearance. The importer may obtain from the Central Bank the foreign exchange to settle his obligations as they become due, up to the total amount authorized in the import license, within 25 banking days after 120 days have elapsed since the date of shipment of the goods. In the case of imports effected through letters of credit, the importer may obtain from the Central Bank foreign exchange for the equivalent of up to 20 percent of the amount authorized in the import license. In the case of imports of raw materials for the manufacture of goods intended for exports by exporting firms registered with the Foreign Trade Institute, the importer may obtain from the Central Bank foreign exchange for the equivalent of up to 50 percent of the amount authorized in the import license issued by the Foreign Trade Institute. In both cases, the Central Bank issues a Certificate of Availability of Foreign Exchange for the total amount authorized minus the amount released earlier, which is valid for 360 days from the date of opening of the letter of credit. The importer must submit this certificate to the Central Bank (within 90 banking days from the date of customs clear- ance) to obtain from the Central Bank (within 25 banking days after 120 days have elapsed since the date of shipment of the goods) the remaining foreign exchange to settle the obligations under the letter of credit as they fall due. In the case of imports effected directly by public sector entities, foreign exchange equivalent to up to 100 percent of the authorized amount in the import license issued by the Ministry of Finance will be provided by the Central Bank within 60 days after submission by the public sector agency of the import license to the Central Bank. In accordance with the timetable issued by the Andean Pact Commission contained in the Protocol of Lima, 511 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA Venezuela adopted the minimum external tariff in 1978 (Decree No. 2772 of August 3, 1978). It agreed, in principle, to harmonize external tariffs and eliminate all import duties on trade within the Andean subregion by December 31, 1983, in the prescribed annual stages. Payments for Invisibles Interest payments on registered private external debt falling due before December 31, 1983 are allowed to be made through the preferential rate of Bs 4.30 = US$1. Payments for the following categories of invisibles can be made at the rate of Bs 7.50 = US$1: (1) freight and insurance associated with imports made at this rate; (2) interest on the public and registered private external debt falling due after December 31, 1983, including interest on private or public entities' debts falling due after December 6, 1986 if the debtor chooses to opt for the exchange rate guarantee scheme; and (3) most outward remittances to students until December 31, 1987. The following invisible payments are effected at the rate of Bs 14.50 per US$1: (1) freight and insurance associated with imports made at this rate; (2) interest on the external debt of the Central Government or serviced by the Central Government; (3) other public sector current payments abroad; (4) outward remittances to some students until end-1987, and to all students thereafter; and (5) interest payments on regis- tered private debts not covered by the exchange rate guarantee scheme. Other payments for invisibles can be made through the free market, without limit. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to South Africa are prohibited. Exports of certain furs and hides, scrap metal, and a few other commodities are prohibited. Licenses are required for the export of commodities subject to price controls or deemed to be in short supply domestically; for most commodities, such licenses are issued by the Ministry of Development, but those for coffee, cacao, rice, and sugar are granted by the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock. The export of precious stones and gold requires an export license issued by the Ministry of Finance. All export earnings by companies dealing in gold must be surrendered to the Central Bank at the exchange rate it uses for its operations in the free market. In the case of private exporters, the authorization to export is contingent on agreement to sell export proceeds to authorized banks within 30 days of shipment in the case of cash exports, and within 10 days of the due payment date in the case of exports on credit. All export earnings are to be surrendered at the rate of Bs 14.4925 = US$1. Exporters of coffee and cacao may receive an export subsidy calculated to prevent the f.o.b. bolivar prices of these products in Venezuelan imports from falling below specified minimum amounts, regardless of external prices. In principle, the benefit of these arrangements may be extended to firms processing domestic coffee or cacao for export. The promotion of nontraditional exports in Venezuela takes three basic forms: (1) the Export Fi- 512 nancing Fund, established in September 1973, provides direct credit facilities at interest rates below those charged by other lenders, and it also lends in conjunction with commercial banks; (2) the Export Incentive Law (Sep- tember 1973) assists nontraditional exports through fiscal subsidies in the form of tax credit certificates; and (3) exporters' access to foreign exchange for imports is facilitated. Under the Export Incentive Law, negotiable tax credit certificates with a two-year maturity are granted to ex- porters of nontraditional products (i.e., exports other than petroleum, iron ore, coffee, and cacao) that have a domestic value added greater than 30 percent. These certificates can be held to maturity and used to meet government tax liabilities, or can be traded in the local market at a discount. For the purpose of calculating the amount of the export subsidy, the domestic currency equivalent of the export value is calculated at the rate of Bs 14.50 = US$1. For firms exporting more than 15 percent of their production or more than US$250,000 per year, separate semiannual quotas for imports of raw materials, spare parts, and semifinished products are established at the beginning of each year; the Directorate of Imports issues individual import permits on the basis of these firms' applications and within their special import programs. Foreign inves tment projects or joint ventures with at least 80 percent production for exports may be authorized to effect all foreign exchange transactions through the free exchange market, except to the extent needed to cover bolivar operating costs. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles are to be surrendered at the rate of Bs 14.50 per US$1, except for receipts from tourism, which are freely disposable. Travelers may freely import domestic and foreign currency, with the exception that importation for commercial purposes of foreign coin other than gold coin is prohibited. Capital The national and local governments, autonomous agen- cies, and state enterprises (other than petroleum and iron ore companies) are required to surrender to the Central Bank at the rate of Bs 14.50 = US$1 all exchange proceeds from foreign borrowing; principal repayments on registered external debt of public sector entities are effected at the rate of Bs 7.50 = US$1, if covered by the exchange guarantee scheme, and principal repayments on the external debt contracted or serviced by the Central Government and on debts of public entities not covered by that scheme are effected at the rate of Bs 14.50 = US$1. All foreign exchange brought into Venezuela by the Venezuelan Investment Fund is subject to conversion at the rate of Bs 14.50 = US$1. Principal repayments of registered external private debt can be effected at the rate of Bs 4.30 = US$1, if the debt amounts to US$500,000 or less and is in the form of export credits with foreign official guarantee and fell due prior to July 17, 1986, or in the form of certificates of deposit or foreign currency ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution deposits. Registered debt amounting to between US$500,000 and US$1 million and export credits with foreign official guarantee due after July 17, 1986, but prior to the signing of a contract between the debtor and the Central Bank, can be amortized immediately at the rate of Bs 7.50 per US$1. For the remainder of private registered debts, amortization may take place on the respective dates of maturity at the rate of Bs 7.50 per US$1 under an optional exchange rate guarantee scheme. Debt eligible for registration was defined as the net liabilities position in foreign exchange as of February 18, 1983 of (1) banking, financial, and insurance companies; and (2) nonfinancial enterprises of mixed or Venezuelan ownership in the areas of manufacturing (if the debt was contracted for the acquisition of capital goods for use within the country), transportation and public services (if the debt was for the acquisition of equipment), and construction (if the debt was incurred for public sector works or works guaranteed by the public sector for social housing projects). Under the exchange rate guarantee scheme, debtors can acquire guaranteed access to foreign exchange at the rate of Bs 7.50 per US$1 for servicing their registered debts, over a period of eight years, by paying in advance a premium in bolivares. For private debts, the premium is Bs 3 per US$1 for amortization payments, and an additional variable premium of up to Bs 1.50 for each US$1 of registered debt for interest payments.4 A similar exchange rate guarantee scheme exists for external debts of state enterprises and auton- omous institutions that were contracted prior to February 18, 1983.5 Debtors have the option of subscribing to the exchange rate guarantee for part or all of the amortization payments or for part or all of the interest payments. Any debt-service payments of registered debt eligible for this scheme, but not subscribed to it by the debtor, can be channeled through the controlled exchange market at the rate in effect at the time of payment. In both cases, regardless of whether the exchange guarantee is sub- scribed, amortization payments are to be effected ac- cording to a prescribed (backloaded) schedule, and the interest rate is to be limited to LIBOR plus VA percentage points. Debtors may defer the payment of the premium over the eight-year period, in line with the schedule of debt service, by paying interest at a rate linked to domestic lending rates. All other inward and outward capital transfers by residents must be registered with SIEX in order to be eligible for the Bs 14.50 per US$1 exchange rate, although they are permitted without restriction in the freely fluc- tuating exchange market. However, brokerage activity in Venezuela in shares or un i ts of foreign investment trusts or mutual funds is prohibited. Foreign capital imported for investment purposes and all foreign credits must be 4 The premium varies according to the foreign interest rate under which interest payments are to be covered by the exchange rate guarantee (about Bs 0.17 per percentage point), up to a max imum rate of 9 percent. 5 In accordance w i th the longer repayment period established for such debts, the premium has been set somewhat higher than for private debts (Bs 3.50 for each U.S. dollar of principal, and Bs 0.25 for each percentage point of interest covered). VENEZUELA registered with SIEX. Foreign direct investment is gov- erned by Andean Pact regulations; a new foreign invest- ment code, however, has resulted in a substantial liber- alization of the system. Natural gas and iron mining operations are reserved for the State, and foreign invest- ment in the petroleum sector is prohibited; this restriction may, however, be lifted in exceptional cases. The Central Bank regulates bank credit to nonresidents and companies whose capital is more than 50 percent owned by physical persons or companies that are resident or domiciled abroad. The General Banking Law authorizes the Gov- ernment to regulate bank credit to companies whose capital is more than 40 percent owned by nonresident or foreign physical persons or companies. This law also regulates the activities of foreign banks operating in Venezuela. Interest earnings on loans extended by foreign financial institutions are exempt from the income tax. Decree 1521 and Exchange Agreement No. 4, in com- bination with the new Foreign Investment Code, regulate the conversion of public sector external debt into equity or financial assets in Venezuela. Debt-equity conversion is allowed if the intended investment is directed either at import substitution, export industries, preventing closure of Venezuelan enterprises, or 1 of 11 priority sectors. For a period of three years, after-tax dividend and profit remittances are limited to an annual rate of 10 percent of the converted debt; remittances in subsequent years are subject to the rules of the Foreign Investment Code. No capital repatriation is allowed for a period of five years, and during the following eight years, repatriation is limited to a maximum annual rate of 12.5 percent. The Central Bank acquires the foreign debt at par or at a discount to be determined in each individual case at an exchange rate o f Bs 14.4925 per US$1. Gold Venezuelan gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may hold, acquire, and sell gold coins in Venezuela for numismatic and investment purposes. The Central Bank does not deal in gold with the public, but gold coin, medallions, and bars are freely negotiated among authorized importers and exchange houses and the public. Commercial banks may freely negotiate gold coin among themselves and with other residents but do not normally deal in gold with the public. Imports and exports of monetary gold are reserved for the Central Bank, as are imports of gold coins that are legal tender in Venezuela. Imports and exports of nonmonetary gold (other than jewelry for personal use) and of gold coins eligible as legal tender in Venezuela or abroad are subject to prior authorization by the Central Bank. In addition, imports require licenses from the Central Bank and in certain cases also from the Minister of Development; exports require authorization by the Central Bank. As an incentive measure, export earnings by companies dealing in gold are converted by the Central Bank at the free market rate. The law prescribes a license for all imports and exports of gold by anyone not registered at the 513 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET NAM (Position on December 31, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Viet Nam is the Dong. The exchange rate is quoted in terms of the U.S. dollar, to which it is pegged, and adjustments are made at irregular intervals. External transactions w i th the countries of the Council for Economic Assistance (CMEA) are settled in transfer- able rubles through clearing arrangements administered by the International Bank for Economic Cooperation (IBEC). Transactions w i th Albania, the Lao People's Democratic Republic, and the Democratic People's Re- public of Korea are settled with clearing (or bilateral) rubles. On October 15, 1987 the exchange rate of the dong for external trade transactions in terms of the U.S. dollar was adjusted from D 18 to D 225 per US$1, and the transferable ruble rate was adjusted from D 18 to D 150 per one transferable ruble. On December 1, 1987 the official exchange rate used for noncommercial transac- tions was adjusted from D 80 to D 368 per US$1, and the clearing ruble rate was adjusted from D 45 to D 240 per one clearing ruble. Un t il December 1, 1987 a 20 percent premium had been added to the official rate applied to international organizations based in Viet Nam and tour- ists; after that date, the premium was no longer applied to tourists. The rate applicable to inward remittances was changed several times during 1987. On April 21 the rate was adjusted from D 96 per US$1 to D 396 per US$1. On July 21 the rate was adjusted to D 504 per US$1.1 Following the fu lf i l lment of the export plan against the delivery of input by the Government, export-producing enterprises are entitled either to retain 10-30 percent of export earnings in deposits in foreign currencies or to use foreign exchange at their discretion; the remainder is required to be surrendered to the Government. In the case of exports not covered by the plan, the enterprises are entitled either to retain 70-90 percent of export earnings in deposits in foreign currencies or to use foreign exchange at their descretion; the remainder is required to be surrendered to the Government. In addition, import corporations receive export subsidies from the budget to cover their production and procurement costs, and the export subsidy fund that is operated for this purpose is financed by profits from import sales. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the State Bank of Viet Nam. Foreign trade is administered by the Ministry of Foreign Trade, which authorizes the foreign trade transactions carried out by specialized import-export corporations and some cooperatives or state enterprises. Import and export licenses are issued by the Ministry of 1 This rate was ad jus ted to D 900 per US$1 on February 24, 1988. Foreign Trade; approval is given for imports in excess of the plan on the merit of each application. Most official foreign exchange transactions are effected by the Bank for Foreign Trade. Most of the foreign exchange trans- actions related to foreign technical assistance are moni- tored by the Aid Reception Commission, which is an agency directly attached to the Cabinet of the Prime Minister. Arrears are maintained with respect to external payments. Prescription of Currency Trade transactions with member countries of the CMEA are settled under the transferable ruble system adminis- tered by the IBEC. Transactions with Albania, the Lao People's Democratic Republic, and the Democratic Peo- ple's Republic of Korea are settled through individual clearing accounts using clearing (or bilateral) rubles. As a member of the CMEA, Viet Nam is entitled to use credits in transferable rubles from the IBEC to facilitate the clearing of transactions with the CMEA member countries. Viet Nam is also entitled to use credits from the IBEC to finance its external trade deficit with the CMEA countries, pending the conclusion of medium- or long-term financing arrangements with the trade parties. Viet Nam maintains a special current account in con- vertible foreign exchange with the IBEC for a petroleum joint venture between Viet Nam and the U.S.S.R. Non- trade transactions with countries with which Viet Nam has bilateral payments agreements2 take place at exchange rates specified in those agreements. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents are permitted to maintain nonresident accounts either in foreign currencies or in convertible dong. Nonresidents can freely reconvert into foreign currency and transfer abroad unused balances in Viet- namese currency that have been acquired against foreign currency. Imports and Exports An import plan and an export plan are drawn up annually on the basis of the overall annual plan and quotas agreed upon under bilateral trade arrangements. Import and export activities are regulated by Decision No. 177, which was issued by the Council of Ministers on June 15, 1985. Trade transactions are carried out by 28 centrally managed import-export corporations and 22 local trading compa- nies, which produce exportable goods themselves or purchase them from producers. Under a system intro- 2 At the end of 1987, Viet Nam maintained bilateral payments agreements with three member countries of the Fund —the Lao People's Democratic Republic, Mali, and the Syrian Arab Republic (only the agreement with the Lao People's Democratic Republic was operative), and with two countries that are not members of the Fund —Albania and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea. 515 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution VIET NAM duced in 1987, some other enterprises can export directly, if the annual value exceeds US$2 million. All payments for external trade transactions are made through the Bank for Foreign Trade; export receipts are also normally channeled through the Bank for Foreign Trade. Local export companies are permitted to export all available commodities, including the 25 items previously under the monopoly of the central export-import com- panies. Local corporations may import only commodities appearing on a list approved by the Ministry of Foreign Trade, which is amended periodically. The procurement prices of exportable commodities and the domestic prices of imported goods are determined by local companies within ranges that are set by the State Pricing Commission for each group of commodities. In order to make better use of available marketing expertise and facilities, local trading companies in the provinces are permitted to enter into joint venture arrangements with trading companies located in various municipalities. Export companies benefit from subsidies whenever their procurement costs are not fully covered by the international prices of their exports converted to domestic currency at the exchange rate that is applied to trade transactions. For centrally managed companies, these subsidies are made available by the Export Support Fund, which is maintained by the Ministry of Finance. For locally managed companies these subsidies are paid out of profits made on imports, with the balance paid by the local government. Export permits are only granted when export subsidies do not exceed pre-established norms. An export bonus system has been in operation since 1980 to provide additional incentives for export produc- tion. Since June 15, 1985, the bonus for collective pro- duction units (cooperatives, cooperation teams, and pro- duction collectives) amounts to 4-5 percent of the value in domestic currency of their production of export goods if their plan quota is fulfilled. Central and local companies fulfilling their export quota are granted foreign exchange equivalent to 10 percent of their export earnings to import required inputs. Local trading companies are required to surrender 10-30 percent of their export earnings (in convertible currencies) that exceed the quota delivered to the State. However, many exemptions currently apply. For locali- ties that borrow in foreign currency, the surrender re- quirement is applied to their export earnings, net of their debt-servicing paymen ts, for a period of three to five years; companies operating in the highland area are exempted from surrendering foreign exchange for a period of five years after they start producing exportable goods. Centrally managed companies operating in the tourist sectors are exempted from the surrender requirement, and central companies exporting coal, rubber, and marine products are allowed to retain 80-100 percent of their export earnings to purchase necessary inputs from the convertible area. Deposits arising from foreign currency receipts are held in special domestic currency accounts that can be used for the purchase of foreign currency for imports. The right to use these convertible dong deposits 516 can be relinquished to other enterprises in exchange for the supply of inputs. State enterprises have two export plans. Primary export plans are formulated by the Government against deliveries of key inputs by the Government; secondary plans are set by the producing units without a sufficient supply of inputs (e.g., fuel) by the Government, thus leaving the task of procuring the needed inputs to the enterprises. New taxes on international trade were approved in December 1987, and they became effective in early 1988. Import duties ranging from 5 percent to 55 percent, with the majority of rates not exceeding 20 percent, were introduced. The lowest rates are levied on imports of raw materials and capital equipment, and the highest rates are levied on imports of consumer goods classified as luxuries (previously, import duties were levied only on noncom- mercial imports, and this duty was retained). The export taxes for most products range up to 10 percent. The taxes on international trade are calculated on the basis of the exchange rate applied to trade transactions (D 225 in December 1987). For imports from the nonconvertible currency area, annual foreign exchange is allocated to importers on the basis of actual production capacity; in principle, such foreign exchange cannot be carried over from one year to the next. For imports from the convertible area, although a similar foreign exchange allocation system exists in principle, it is not in use, as decisions to allocate foreign exchange are taken by the Prime Minister's Cabinet on a case-by-case basis, on recommendations from the State Planning Commission, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Foreign Trade, and specified Vice-Premiers. For transactions under the local produc- tion plans, local authorities are authorized to decide on foreign exchange allocation, provided that the resources are derived from their retained export earnings. Payments for Invisibles All transactions in invisibles require individual author- ization by the Ministry of Finance. Foreign exchange is made available upon authorization of the transaction. All travel abroad needs individual authorization from the Prime Minister's Cabinet, and is limited to official busi- nesses for which all reasonable foreign exchange expenses are covered.3 Receipts from transactions in invisibles must be surrendered to the Ministry of Finance. The export and import of Vietnamese currency and of securities denominated in Vietnamese currency need the special permission of the State Bank. The circulation of foreign currency in the domestic market is prohibited. Legal holders of foreign exchange are authorized to buy foreign and local consumer goods in special government shops, and tourists are required to make certain payments in convertible foreign currency. 3 As from February 1988, p r iva te travel has been permitted for specified reasons, including s tudy, health, and visiting relatives abroad. In the latter case, the traveler mu st have a round - t r ip t icket and adequate funds provided by transfers from the relatives abroad. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Capital A new law on foreign investment was approved by the National Assembly on December 29, 1987, providing for three forms of foreign investment: (1) contracted business cooperation, such as product-sharing arrangements; (2) joint ventures between a foreign investor and a Vietnam- ese state economic organization; and (3) categories wholly owned by foreign investors. The permitted share of foreign capital is to be no less than 30 percent, and there is no upper limit. Other provisions under the Investment Code include: (1) the duration of the enterprise with foreign capital, not to exceed 20 years, but if necessary, to be extended for a longer period; (2) a tax of 5-10 percent, to be levied on remittance of profits abroad; (3) income taxes, to be paid at the reduced rates of 15-25 percent, starting two years after the first profit-making year; and (4) possible exemptions from or reductions of import and export duties in exceptional cases. The Code also provides that foreign investors need to deal only with one orga- nization within the Government specifically created for that purpose. Gold The State Bank alone has the authority to purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. Individuals are permitted to own jewelry and artistic and cultural objects of gold for domestic and personal use. VIET NAM Changes During 1987 Exchange Arrangement April 21. Not for Redistribution WESTERN SAMOA (Position on December 31, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of Western Samoa is the Western Samoa Tala. The exchange rate of the tala is determined on the basis of a weighted basket of currencies. On December 31, 1987 the buying and selling rates of the tala in terms of the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, were WS$1 = US$0.5018 and WS$1 = US$0.4928, respectively. Exchange rates for other currencies are established on the basis of their daily rates against the U.S. dollar. There is an exchange levy of 1 percent on gross sales of foreign exchange, resulting in spreads between the buying and selling rates in excess of 2 percent in exchange transac- tions. There are no arrangements for forward cover against exchange rate risk in the official or the commercial banking sector. Administration of Control Overall responsibility for the administration of ex- change control rests with the Central Bank of Samoa, which may delegate part of its powers to authorized banks. In principle, all payments to nonresidents of Western Samoa require the approval of the Central Bank of Samoa; the Bank of Western Samoa and the Pacific Commercial Bank —the only authorized banks—are em- powered to approve certain payments up to any amount, and certain other payments up to specified amounts. Prescription of Currency There are no prescriptions as to the currencies in which payments to or from nonresidents of Western Samoa must be made or received. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between the accounts of resi- dents and nonresidents of Western Samoa. Imports and Import Payments The import of a few commodities is prohibited for reasons of security or health. Other commodities may be imported from any source without restriction, with the exception of items subject to special approval on a case- by-case basis, namely motor vehicles, capital equipment in excess of dutiable values of WS$10,000, and a few items for which there are domestically manufactured substitutes.1 Import transactions other than for petroleum products and exceeding WS$5,000 are in each case re- quired to be made under letters of credit. Payments for Invisibles Payments for certain invisibles may be approved by the authorized banks up to specified limits. Payments in 1 Beer, cigarettes, timber, veneer, matches, and disposable cigarette lighters, sandals/thongs, bottled and canned soft drinks, and ice cream and ice cream products. 518 excess of these limits, as well as payments for all other invisibles, require the prior approval of the Central Bank. Remittances for study abroad are normally authorized. Approval of the Central Bank of Samoa is required in respect of all transfers of local earnings from dividends, interest, and pensions of overseas residents. Residents and expatriates traveling overseas for private purposes are entitled to a foreign currency allowance equivalent to WS$100 a person a day, subject to a limit of WS$2,000 a person a year; in the case of travel for business purposes, the daily allowance is WS$200 within a limit of WS$4,000 a trip. The Central Bank of Samoa grants supplementary allocations against evidence of genuine need. As part of their foreign currency allowance, resident travelers may take out foreign bank notes equivalent to WS$500 a person. Travelers may not take out any domestic cur- rency. A 15 percent withholding tax is levied on remit- tances of dividends at the source and interest payments on overseas loans. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require export licenses issued by the Cus- toms Department. Exports may be prohibited by the Director of Agriculture and the Produce Marketing Di- vision on grounds of low quality, or by order of the Head of State to alleviate domestic shortages. Exports of cocoa are controlled by the Cocoa Board. An export levy of 7 percent is imposed on the f.o.b. value of cocoa.2 Export proceeds from goods shipped to countries other than American Samoa must be surrendered to the au- thorized banks within four months from the date of shipment; export proceeds from goods shipped to Amer- ican Samoa must be surrendered to the authorized bank within four weeks from the date of shipment. Certificates validated by an authorized bank are required for exports in excess of WS$250. The following rates of export levies are applied: copra, 5 percent, activated at prices in excess of WS$100 per ton; copra meal, 3 percent; fruits and vegetables, 3 percent; veneer logs and sawn logs, 20 percent; rough timber, 5 percent to 15 percent; and coconut oil, WS$25 per metric ton. Proceeds from Invisibles All foreign currencies earned by residents in performing services for nonresidents must be surrendered to the authorized banks. Resident travelers must on return sell to the banks all unused foreign currency brought in. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign bank notes, but may not bring in any domestic bank notes. 2 The export levy on cocoa is activated at prices in excess of WS$800 a ton. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Capital All outward capital transfers by residents require the specific approval of the Central Bank of Samoa. Inward capital remittances do not normally require approval, but borrowing abroad by nonbank residents does require approval. The authorized banks approve transfers of gifts to relatives and dependents, either for special family occasions or by way of maintenance, up to WS$250 a year a person. Foreign investments in specified activities in Western Samoa are encouraged. The Enterprises In- centive Act provides for the granting of certain relief of income tax and business license fees to persons engaged in approved enterprises. Both the repatriation of capital and profit remittances on foreign capital are subject to approval by the Central Bank of Samoa; such approval is normally granted. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form. There are no restrictions on imports or exports of gold. WESTERN SAMOA Changes During 1987 Imports and Import Payments March 9. Not for Redistribution YEMEN ARAB REPUBLIC (Position on December 31, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of the Yemen Arab Republic is the Yemen Rial, which is pegged to the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, at YRls 8.99 = US$1.1 On December 31, 1987 the official buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were YRls 8.98 and YR ls 9.90, respectively, per US$1. Buying and selling rates for certain other currencies2 are fixed daily by the Central Bank of Yemen in its transac- tions, on the basis of rates for the U.S. dollar in markets abroad. These central bank rates apply to limited public sector transactions.3 The Central Bank is the sole buyer and seller of foreign exchange in the domestic banking system. It purchases foreign exchange mainly from money changers (mainly in Jeddah) who acquire foreign exchange from Yemeni workers in Saudi Arabia, and credits the accounts of the money changers with commercial banks in the Yemen Arab Republic. The exchange rate for these transactions, which constitutes the commercial bank rate, is negotiated. Commercial banks are allowed to purchase foreign exchange domestically (from tourists, etc.), but must sell any foreign exchange acquired to the Central Bank. Any external borrowing by commercial banks must be ap- proved by the Central Bank. The Central Bank provides foreign exchange to all holders of import licenses at the commercial bank rate. At the end of 1987, the commercial bank rate fluctuated around YRls 9.9 - US$1. An exchange rate of YRls 10 = US$1 i s u s e d f o r t he settlement of letters of credit. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. There is a large informal market in foreign exchange, mainly involving money changers in Jeddah, remittances agents, and Yemen Arab Republic citizens who have been or are working abroad. Although money changers are not officially permitted to operate in the Yemen Arab Republic, their activity is tolerated. Otherwise, individ- uals and companies are free to buy, hold, and sell foreign exchange. The exchange rate in this market forms the basis for the commercial rate. Administration of Control A foreign exchange budget is established by the Central Bank in parallel with a commodity budget prepared by the Ministry of Economy, Commerce, and Supply in consultation with the Central Bank. Not for Redistribution PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN (Position on December 31, 1987) Exchange Arrangement The currency of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen is the Yemeni Dinar, which is pegged to the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, at YD 1 = US$2.89524. Buying and selling rates for the pound sterling are also officially quoted by the National Bank of Yemen (the sole commercial bank and authorized dealer), with daily quotations based on the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar in markets abroad. On December 31, 1987 the National Bank of Yemen's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were YD 0.343 and YD 0.350, respec- tively, per US$1. Rates for all other prescribed currencies are quoted weekly; additional adjustments are made when there are major changes in the market rates for these currencies in London and New York the previous day. There are no taxes or subsidies on purchases or sales of foreign exchange. Administration of Control The administration of exchange control is carried out by the General Department for Exchange Control of the Bank of Yemen (the central bank) through the Foreign Exchange Committee, which has delegated certain powers to the Director of Exchange Control, a member of that Committee. The Ministry of Trade and Supply issues import and export licenses; those for gold and other precious metals require the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control. Exchange transactions must be carried out through the National Bank of Yemen. Other dealers in foreign exchange, who may deal only in traveler's checks and bank notes, are classified into ordinary money changers and secondary dealers. Ordi- nary money changers, whose principal business is to sell and purchase foreign exchange for their own account or for the account of the National Bank, are permitted to deal in specified currencies. Secondary dealers, such as hotels, travel bureaus, and retail stores selling tourist goods, are permitted to accept payment in foreign ex- change only from their customers and are required to surrender the receipts in foreign exchange to the National Bank not later than the following business day. The authorized bank and money changers are allowed to charge a commission for the purchase and sale of foreign exchange as specified by the Committee, but secondary dealers may not do so. Except for payments for imports against letters of credit or documents, which may be approved by the authorized dealer, all payments for imports (including those of precious metals) require the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control. Certain public corporations are engaged in foreign trade (see section on Imports and Import Payments, below). 522 Prescription of Currency Exchange transactions must be carried out through the authorized dealer in accordance with prescription of currency regulations. All payments to Israel are prohib- ited. Export proceeds and certain receipts from invisibles must be received in convertible currencies and surren- dered to the authorized dealer; proceeds from exports or re-exports to specified neighboring countries may be surrendered in the currencies of such countries. Payments for imports must be made in prescribed currencies. Nonresident Accounts External Accounts in Yemeni dinars may be credited with proceeds from convertible foreign currency trans- ferred from abroad, with bank interest payable on such accounts, and with balances from other External Ac- counts. Transfers from abroad must be in the form of bank drafts; the accounts may not be credited with payments in the form of foreign bank notes (unless they have been declared to customs on entry), or with locally raised or locally earned funds (except in certain specified cases). External Accounts may be debited for any pay- ments to residents, for transfers to other External Ac- counts, and for payments abroad in any convertible currency. Transfers abroad from External Accounts in Yemeni dinars require the prior approval of the Exchange Control Department. The Foreign Exchange Committee may direct any payment to a nonresident to a Blocked Account. Except with the Committee's prior approval, Blocked Accounts may be debited only for purchases of specified securities. Yemeni nationals working abroad may establish non- resident accounts in foreign currencies; balances in these accounts earn interest and are convertible into foreign currency on demand. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Israel are prohibited. Imports of cars other than those needed for development projects are also prohibited. All imports require individual licenses. Goods originating in the Yemen Arab Republic are exempt from the licensing requirements. There is an annual import program. Importers may import certain goods with their own exchange; such imports require prior approval by the Ministry of Trade and Supply. Payments for imports on a c. & f. basis against letters of credit or documentary drafts can be made by authorized dealers without the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control; most other forms of payment for imports require approval. Insurance on imports must be effected locally. The National Company for Foreign Trade has a mo- nopoly over imports of all consumer goods, with the exception of medical supplies and hospital equipment, which are handled by the National Company for Drugs. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution It is also the sole importer of automobiles and other vehicles, all government requirements, and most require- ments of the public hospitals, as well as other specified items. Imports into and exports from the free port zones within the port of Aden are free of exchange and trade controls (except in respect of transactions between these zones and the rest of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen) and are exempt from customs duties, except that the proceeds of exports and re-exports financed originally by the authorized bank are subject to the surrender requirement (see section on Prescription of Currency, above). In all cases, exporters from the free zones are required to undertake to repatriate in convertible currencies commissions, profits, and other expenses re- lating to the processing of goods in the zones and to surrender the currencies to the authorized bank. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require prior approval by the Director of Exchange Control. The "Inducement to Invest Law" divides foreign investments into two cate- gories: (1) projects that realize self-sufficiency in their requirements for foreign currency, which may remit net annual profits due on invested capital within the limit of the credit of their exports; and (2) projects of primary importance for the national economy, which may remit the whole of the annual net profits due on capital invested. Projects that were set up prior to 1971 may remit all of their net profit. The basic exchange allowance for tourism is the equiv- alent of YD 100 a person a trip to all destinations other than the Yemen Arab Republic (the allowance for the Yemen Arab Republic is YRls 2,000); for children aged between 2 and 10 years, the basic exchange allowance is one half of these amounts. Allowances for medical treat- ment abroad are normally granted in accordance with the amount estimated by the Ministry of Health. Allowances for other types of travel are granted on the merits of each application. Foreign employees of approved enterprises are allowed to remit abroad between 50 percent and 100 percent of their total earnings (net of taxes) according to the terms of the contract; other foreign employees, if receiving their salaries from abroad, are allowed to remit 70 percent of their total earnings. Nonnationals doing business in the country can remit abroad up to the equivalent of YD 50 a month for family maintenance. All insurance is nation- alized; existing policies have been transferred to the National Insurance and Reinsurance Company, and pay- ments abroad in respect of premiums are not permitted. Travelers may take out the equivalent of YD 5 in domestic bank notes and up to the equivalent of YD 125 in traveler's checks, foreign bank notes, or other foreign means of payment. Nonresidents may take out any foreign ex- change declared upon entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports are subject to individual licensing. All exports to Israel are prohibited. Except for exports to PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN neighboring countries specified by the Foreign Exchange Committee, export proceeds must be received in con- vertible currencies within six months of shipment and must be sold to authorized dealers upon receipt. Proceeds of exports or re-exports to neighboring countries may be surrendered in the national currency of the importing country. Proceeds from Invisibles All claims of residents for services rendered to non- residents must be collected in foreign currency (or re- ceived from an External Account) and surrendered to the authorized dealer. Travelers may freely bring in foreign bank notes; imports of more than YD 5 in domestic currency are subject to a tax of 50 percent. Tourists are required to spend in foreign exchange an amount equiv- alent to YD 50 a month or US$10 a day if the duration of their stay is less than one month. Capital Virtually all capital payments and transactions require prior approval. Expatriates are normally permitted upon departure to remit their entire savings to their country of permanent residence. Foreign investments that have been approved under the Inducement to Invest Law (enacted in 1981) may be granted exemptions from import duty and various other tax facilities. Five years after invest- ment, the net value of the enterprise (calculated on the basis of assignment, actual liquidation, or book value, whichever is less) is transferable at the rate of 25 percent a year; if, however, the owner of the Yemeni, Arab, or foreign capital encounters operational difficulties, his capital may, upon approval, be re transferred to its place of origin one year after entry. This provision also applies to the reinvested part of such capital. Interest due on any loans obtained abroad after the firm concerned has been established may also be remitted, provided that all duties, taxes, and other government dues have been paid. Projects authorized under this law are exempt from income tax for up to five years from the commencement of production and may carry losses forward. Gold Only the monetary authorities and authorized dealers may purchase, hold, or sell gold bullion. Licensed gold- smiths may purchase, hold, and sell other unworked gold and gold coin and ornaments. Other residents may hold gold in the form of ornaments or numismatic coins. Exports and imports of gold by registered goldsmiths require licenses issued by the Ministry of Trade and Supply (General Department for Foreign Trade); in certain cases, the consent of the Foreign Exchange Committee must also be obtained. Departing female residents may take out gold ornaments not exceeding 20 tolas,1 subject to registration in their passports. Arriving female nationals may bring in gold ornaments up to 25 tolas duty free and up to an additional 75 tolas after paying import duty at a 1 One tola is equal to 180 grains troy or 0.4114 ounce. 523 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN rate of 30 percent.
